Big white head that quickly dissipates. Sweet and malty with little to no hop aroma or biterness. Hazy yellow color and very little alcohol taste for 8%.
Bottle. Hazy yellow colour with a big longlasting white head. Swet malty aroma. Sweet malty fruity and yeasty flavor, with some spicy hints. Sweet malty spicy finish.

0,33l bottle. HUGE white head, which settles at last. Bubbling like champagne, but very grainy (pun intended). Complex nose, too complex for me I suppose. Melis, rhubarb, lavendel, citrus is somewhere there. Extremely big beer. Soothing aftertaste, good and smooth transition.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2006 330 ml bottle.
Pours golden with a nice head. The aroma is deeply fruity - lemon and orange, some honey, plenty of spice. The flavor follows, offering a lovely sweetness on the front and a fine bitter finish. 

 I¬ím not bowled over by the complexity of this one, but that may have been the circumstances rather than the beer, and I¬íll be absolutely delighted to revisit.
On Tap.  Small head.  Medium carbonation.  Clear golden color.  Good structure in mouth.  Nice citrus and caramel taste.

Poured a hazy bright yellow with a huge amount of froathy white head that does not go away one bit.  Aroma is caramel, lemon, banana, and slight brandy alcohol.  Flavor was much more bitter than i expected from a tripel, citrus lemon flavor definitely there.  Overall, decent, but not my favorite.

this is a trippel (i would have just written that over and over but a review might be helpful)...appetizing o ya!...fruity and delcious...big fizzy head..very complex...i can see this brewer makes deus...sprintzy...1 of the best trippels ever!

Aroma: sweet, malty, yeast, metal, fruit, hay
Appearance: large head initially, mostly diminishing, fair lacing, golden/yellow/sparkling 
Flavor: moderately sweet, lightly bitter, 
Palate:  body-medium, texture-dry/watery, carbonation-soft, finish-metalic/alcohol

Overall:  It has been one of my favorite Tripels so far....    the fruitiness comes out if you have it at the right temp.... which I think should be only slightly chilled....
 and someone mentioned flowers in the taste...  I can totally get that....

poured with an extremely lively head so beware. fruity aroma, peaches maybe or pear?, brilliant sparkle to the beer, golden colour very nice to look at and even better to taste, slightly dry on the finish, more fruit at the very end, my first try at a triple but will have to find some more. very enjoyable

Bottle.  Cork popped off and hit my ceiling.  Pours clear golden with big bubbly and fluffy white head.  Aroma is spicy, fruity, earthy and alcohol.  Taste is fruity up front like plums/peaches  and then smoothes out with yeasty and malt.  Finishes with a peach taste.  Finishes dry.  Medium body.  Nice carbonation, like a sparkling wine.  Not bad.
Bottle. Hazy yellow colour with a big longlasting white head. Swet malty aroma. Sweet malty fruity and yeasty flavor, with some spicy hints. Sweet malty spicy finish.

Big head. Be careful when pouring this beer. The taste is very good and complex and the aroma is very nice as well. Strong corbonation gives this beer a sparkling white or champagne like texture and it compliments the wheat and fruit like taste

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 Bottle from the World Beer Festival - Richmond on 06/20/2010. Slightly hazy golden body with a medium rocky white head. Spicy and belgian aroma. Spicy belgian flavor with sweet malt. Medium body with high carbonation. 6/3/7/4/14 - 3.4

06/21/2006 - Clear dark golden color with a creamy white head. Sweet candi sugar aroma. Sweet caramel malt aroma and hints of candi sugar. 7/3/7/3/14 - 3.4

750ml corked bottle. Bright gold with huge white head, last pour hazy with yeast sediment. Nose of apples, pear, hay, metal, mineral, funk, yeast, and some malt sweetness. Flavor is a nice blend of light fruit and dry yeast, slightly sweet throughout, with a drying, biting finish. Lively carbonation is not overdone. Nicely done, could be a bit deeper in flavors.

Bottle. White very high astonishingly creamy and good-looking head. Hazy light yellow body. Banana aroma. Flavor dominated by carbonation and a pleasant bitterness. Not what I expected from a beer whith banana flavor and a head like that. Pleasant surprise.

bottle.  Aroma:  First smell is skunkiness (damn you green bottles!).  Later I get green apples and golden raisins, along with some sweet malt and an herbal smell.  Appearance:  Slightly hazy and light gold in color.  Head was white and voluminous, but quickly died away.  Not much lacing.  Flavor:  Slight skunkiness in flavor.  After that,  it¬ís raisins, coriander, orange, and wheat.  Belgian yeast flavor not as present as would be expected.  Alcohol tasted slightly in very back of mouth.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Carbonation was lively.  Slightly sour aftertaste and nice alcohol warming on back of tongue and roof of mouth.  Overall:  If this had not been slightly skunked, I would have rated it higher.  I¬íll try to re-rate in the future.  Besides the skunkiness, this is a very good, easy to drink, and accessible Tripel.

Dark yellow colored, hazy appearance. Big white head. Aroma is great: spices, touch of fruits and medium alcohol, which fits here well. Medium to full bodied. Flavor has also strong spices with vinous anis tones, aftertaste has obvious, almost too strong alcohol. Ending turns out to be slightly dry. World class tripel!

Pours yellow, white head, bubbling profusely, cloudy. Some malt, hops, flowers, bramley apples. Some off-sour smell there too. Taste iis slightly bitter, some apples, gassy, slightly dry aftertaste. No taste of alcohol at all. Easy drinking, smooth, if too carbonated.

Bottle at Novotel, Gent.
Yellow with a large white head, mostly lasting, good lacings. Aroma moderate/heavy malty (apples), light hoppy. Flavor moderate/heavy sweet, light bitter. Medium body, soft carbonated.

Wowsers, this one gives Chimay Cinq (my favorite tripel) a run for its money! Poured a clear and crisp golden yellow with a head that was pillowy and long lasting (and certainly not ridiculous - I actually poured the whole thing into my Chimay glass in one pour). The lacing was outstanding. The aroma was mostly light fruits with a touch of spice. The flavor was just great: rich but not too thick in mouthfeel, with a definite candy sugar sweetness supporting a citrus (orange) tongue that finished with great hoppiness. Yeast flavors were subdued and less prominent than in other tripels. Mouthfeel was pretty heavily carbonated, but the body thinner than most tripels (ie. more drinkable and very pleasant). I will put this side by side a Cinq someday, but prefer it over any of the other tripels I¬íve had.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 Bottle, 33 cl. Clear golden colour with a large white head. Aroma is a bit spicy and smells of resin and bubble gum. Flavour is sweet, fruity with a nice portion of hops. Malty biscuit-finish.
Pours a golden yellow with a huge head that stays around for a while. A light floral / citrus aroma. A real nice beer.

Lavender, rosemary, dough and nectarine aromas dominate a rich floral and herbal profile.  The beer is bright golden and opaque in the glass.  Flavors are as rich and deep as the aromas -- with the addition of caramel and sweet oats.  Complex palate and long finish.  Alcohol is entirely hidden.  A great, rich and savory tripel.
On tap. Golden yellow with thick white head. Sweet raison-like aroma. Taste is smooth raison-caramel with a subtle wheaty finish.

11.2 oz bottle - Pours golden with a big, lasting head.  There¬ís a pleasant aroma with citrus and spice notes.  The taste is sweet and well balanced with excellent citrus flavors.  It¬ís full bodied, yet smooth and very drinkable.  Very nice!

Slighty cloudy straw colour, lovely white fluffy head. Aroma is citrussy and sweet, kind of clovey like a belgian wit. The flavour is also quite citrussy and spicy, with a not so pronounced malt flavour too it. The alcohol is well hidden, and the finish is a little sour. Good, but I couldn¬ít really get into it that much.

Clear yellow colour, with a lot of carbonation resulting in a huge white head. Loveley sweet hoppy aroma, herby, fruity (some citrus, green appel) and some grainy-malty hints. Full palate, some agressive mouthfeel. Finish is sweet-bitter, some alcoholic touches, beautifull balanced. This is a top beer!

My bro brought this up from Orlando. full spicy aroma, citrusy and sweet.hazy golden wth a big foamy head. flavors are full yet refreshing. citrus, spicy, honey, lemon, clove, very smooth, goes down way to easy
Spicy, fruity, full of different flavor, quite complex. Some lemon too. A very good tripple !
A very fine strong Belgian ale.  Fruity and yeasty like many beers of this style and nice full flavours come through.

Bottled.  Golden pour and a frothy white head.  Lovely nose, malty, sweet, floral, spicy, and some yeasty funk, a little cellar in there, too.  Fantastic.  Tastes crisp, sweet, very malty, slightly fruity, spicy, and a touch of alochol in the warm finish.  Heavy.  Complex as all get out, this is one beast of a tripel.

a beautifull unfiltered,jellow-orange
first,big head ,lthen a  nice rim lasting in the glass

many different smells,there is something bitter-spicy,remembering me  ginger,but something wine-like,almoust champagne-like, and some interesting bitter-sweet, malty and a bit of clove,even a smell like some coocking herbs but altough some fruit

the bitter-sweet malty impression grows while drinking it,but  the champagne-like impression too.ginger,middle,smooth carbonated in mouth 

aftertaste spicy,but also champagne-like,bitter-sweet,warm alcohol,but semms not so strong as it is,good fitting of alcohol to the flavours.

 i love it¬ís interesting complexity !!
sweet and bitter, fruity and herbal, -opposits,but fitting here really well together.astonishing freshness for it¬ís strength!!

11.2 oz bottle.  Clear, golden and bubbly.  Jagged white head that slowly dies; tentacles of lace.  Lemon-lime, club soda, a little grass and grain.  Starts wheaty with green apple and unripe pear.  Carb transports just to the edge of bitter.  Nice medium body; almost creamy.  Not flashy but manages to balance the tart/bitterness and carb/body to produce a fine beer.

Light yellow gold body with a huge white head.  Looks somewhat like a Macro in color.  Aroma is sweet and fruity with banana and clove.  Flavor is extremely sweet and fruity, mainly banana, but quite light and pleasant.  Lightly carbonated palate complements the flavor.
UPDATED: MAY 8, 2006 A nice belge, fruity/sweet aroma, likewise in taste.

Bottle Saisnbury¬ís, Banbury 27-04-06. A hazy orange coloured beer with a medium head, the taste is wheaty, oaty and malty also quite sweet and with some spiceiness prseent. A really solid tripel that goes down extremely well.

I¬íve been rating quite a few tripels these days and this is one of the finest.  Very spicey aroma that even has a little heat from the spice.  Chewy medium/full body with a complex fruity, malty, spicey flavor.  Not dry at all, very delicious.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 On tap at Issac newtons with Stegosaurus. Poured  a copper/golden color with a white head. Aroma of citrus, fruit, hops and spices. Flavor was smooth, citrus and spice. Great brew.

Huge white creamy head with some fine lace over clear yellow with ongoing carbonation. Head subsides quickly. Deep, clean, somewhat delicate aroma of old hops, light fruit, and sweetish malts with notes of banana and spices; some alcohol aroma. Light, delicate, velvety taste of sweetish malty with strong old hop overtones with faint mustiness and notes of banana. Aftertaste is old hops with a little bitterness, which lingers. An excellent trippel. Not very powerful, but delicate, balanced, and beautifully drinkable. (0.33l bottle.)

Bouteille verte de 750 ml avec bouchon de li√®ge obtenue via les Importations Priv√©es Bi√®ropholie.  Ar√¥me: Odeur √©normement fruit√©. Apparence: La couleur est blonde orang√©e avec une forte densit√© de bulle. Pr√©sence d¬íun moyen col mousseux, de d√©p√¥t ainsi qu¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt d¬íagrumes, de caramel et une l√©g√®re pointe d¬íalcool. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Pr√©sence de caramel fruit√© en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #465)

Fruity, banana aroma.  Large thick white head.  Lacing is all over the glass.  A fairly clear golden body with champagne bubbles rushing to the top of the glass.  Slowly waiting for the head to shrink.  The nice thing about that is you can let the beer warm up that way.  The alcohol is very well hidden in this.  Similar to Duvel with a dryer finish.  My only complaint is that this beer is slightly one dimensional.  It still is solid for what it is though.
Very nice beer.  Clear gold in color.  Very efferevescent and sweet.  Yeasty, fruity, and wheaty.  Very good.
very smooth... but WAYYY too sweet... if i had wanted champaign i would have bought it..... this is not a man¬ís beer, it is a womans alternative with a little extra kick

On tap at Everybody¬ís pizza.  Big, blond, robust, and spicy.  Just like I like my women.  Not particularly my favorite at the time in the right place, this would be an awesome drink.  Points off for setting if I can do that.
The only reason I did not give this a 20 was because that spot is for my Duvel! This brew was absolutely splendid! Perfectly blonde ale with a great clean head. Excellent smooth yet robust flavour!

Sadly I lack the proper glassware for this beer.  Nonetheless, in a pint glass head was abundent and hung around with some fairly large bubbles.  Color was dark amber with some cloudiness.  Odor was fruity and slightly earthy with a certain effervescence.

First sip revealed a sweet malty taste with very little hop taste.  The beer had what I wrote was a "mature" alcohol taste...a sweet, pleasant slightly burning sensation, like a bourbon.

After some recent bad experiences with what must have been very old imported beer, I have to say this brought me back into the fold.  8% alcohol probably helps this beer stand up over time...and a 98% rating likely means that it moves off the shelf in a reasonable amount of time. 

I got this beer as an 11.2 oz single from my local beer-savvy retailer (Discount Liquor in Milwaukee).

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007 Pale yellow with white head. Yeast, fruit and wheat. Coriander, clove & citrus. Fresh!  Lively carbonation. great filling and a long pleasant finish. (remember too pour it into a large glass because of the carbonation and the fine head)!

Draught at Federal in Durham, NC. Clear golden color with an orange tint. Bubbly white head that laced the glass. Aroma is estery with a touch of brown sugar and apple. Taste is similar, again with the clove and banana, but there is also a sweet candy note with a splash of alcohol. Very very bubbly. Pretty tasty.

Pale yellow, full froth with medium length hang time. Ample residual bubbles with champagne bubbles. Candy malt nose. Big fruit flavors yet dry. The wheat really comes through with a hefewiezen character. A complex brew that is well ballanced with a long tastey finish. Enjoy cold or warm. Highly recommended.
Sweet fruit malt aroma. Clear amber colour with fantastic frothy white head and great lacing. Sweet malt falvour with fuit. Fizzy palate.
I let it warm up like Piscator told me to.  Great carbonation, but not for me.  Too citrusy or something like that.  I am sure this is one of the best out there though.

[on tap, Milano 2006] Shiny amber color, slightly hazy, with a nice pure-white head. Very aromatic, a mix of summer fruits, vanilla, champagne, perfume and a yeasty note in the background. Taste is moderately sweet pleasantly citric (orange, lemon), with spices (coriander) coming through. A definite champagne-like character emerges as you taste white grapes and let the soft carbonation bubbles tickle your palate. Long, dry, citric aftertaste. Perfectly balanced, extremely drinkable. Absolutely dangerous!

Best by 01/01/08.  Pours a hazy gold with a huge, dense, rock solid white head into my giant Tripel Karmeliet tulip, a chalice fit for a king. The carbonation leaves behind a curtain of lacing as it subsides. Big time grains in the aroma, like a saison. Light fruitiness and spicy yeast also in the nose. Samre flavors with the malt adding some richness to the graininess, crisp hops and subtle alcohol in the finish, also. Balanced, medium/full body. Great brew.

From the bottle; it poured a honey, gold color with a great big fizzy head! The aroma is that of banana, vanilla and plenty of yeast, it smells fantastic! For a moment I thought I might just continue to enjoy its aroma and never drink it so as not to be disappointed but I quickly got over that. The flavor and palate are as awesome as the aroma! The carbonation is kind of a lot but it didn¬ít really impede the flavor. This is a great Tripel!

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Hazy orange-gold color with a thin layer of foam. Aroma is spicy. Full of coriander, lemon zest, yeast, malts and biscuits. Flavor begins with a smooth yet spicy malt flavor then goes nicely into a fruity and sweet middle and a malty and spicy finish with a little bit of alcohol. Alcohol is pleasantly hidden under all the wonderful fruit flavors. Very good.

First thing you notice is bubbles like champagne..
Very rich taste, , a little lemon and other refreshing fruits, a bit spicy as well. This would be a great drink in spring or summer to drink outside short bitter aftertaste. Very good.

Looks and smells the part.  I am not a lambic fan, and a wild yeast aroma and flavor is certainly noticeable.  However, this is the best use of those flavors I have enjoyed to date.  It has the full mouthfeel that some lower quality tripels lack, and is much more balanced than many of its sweeter competitors in the category.
Pint @ Ginger Man, Austin: Cloudy orange-yellow color, small head, diminishing.  Aroma of orange, spicy.  Odd spice, orange, fizzy mouthfeel, kind of flat.
Golden yellow color with a thick white head. Lots of banana bread in the aroma and flavor. Pleasing dry finish. Very enjoyable.

Bottled.  Served in a Orval glass.  Hazy like a weiss beer. Plesant aroma of ripe banana.  This has some saaz hops as well.  This is a bit complex, both sweet and spicy.  This tastes similar to Duvel, but drier.
MMMMMMMM.  A great example.  Even if you can¬ít get it in certain, famous Belgian bars, the Tripel Karmeliet is worth seeking out and exploring.  Hypnotic.

Poured a rich gold with a strong, long lasting head.  Aromas of banana and lime are dominate with a hints of softer fruits.  Flavor is very sooth and crisp.  Again banana dominates with the help of vanilla, but a myriad of other fruits and a light spiciness makes for a great depth.  This is probably my favorite tripel or golden ale to date.

On Tap at the Borough Arms, Crewe 06/05/2005
Golden amber coloured with sour fruit and pale aromas. Some spicy flavour. Crisp slightly bitter warming malt finish.
UPDATED: SEP 12, 2009 Got this as a guest beer on tap at the Old Toad. very pleasant aroma of citrus. this beer goes down smooth and sweet. this beer is defiantly worth the hit in the wallet.
Golden amber color with white foaming head. skunky over tone. Bitter rich with a sour malt finish.

goldish straw colored body, nicely carbonated with no head...aroma of citrus fruits, honey, caramel, sugar, and spice...flavor of sugar, spices, caramel, and a light hoppy backbone...very yeasty and grainy characteristics as well...

33 cl bottle. No yeast at the bottom. Yellow cloudy colour with a nice white head. Aroma of yeast, sweetness, spice and some bread and grain too. Flavour of sweetness yeast and grain, ends up alcoholic with a bitter finish.
Hazy gold,large stark white head.Small bead.Yeasty frutiy nose.Spicey yeasty palate,orange peel overtones,mild alcohol heat. Nothing special

Had this the first time in ¬¥t Brugs Beertje in Brugge, Belgium in my early days as a craft brew drinker. Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow. Smells of alcohol and fruity yeast. Sweet and kinda honeyish. Aromas of caramel, earth and yeast. Dry finish wiyh quite a lot of alcohol aromas for the 8%.

A filtered tripel? There is no yeast at all in this. Zero sediment in the bottom and only the last maybe .5 oz added any cloudiness to the beer.  Anyways, this beer has a great and uncharacteristic aroma.  Very fruity and banana, like a hefeweizen.  Very pale, gold in color with a very effervescent head. Flavor is very dull, a little yeast and a little more banana.  What¬ís the deal?  It¬ís not bad but this is pretty lame.  Reminds of Duvel. I don¬ít get it.

Bottle was chunky and hazy will have to try this one again!!  
Strong grapefruit aroma and some sulfur must have been skunked and sitting on the top shelf for a while.  Quite a bit of sediment on the side of the bottle, probably stored wrong.
UPDATED: SEP 11, 2006 Tremendous.  Different from most tripels I¬íve had... this one was creamier, still sweet, with the oats and wheat making for a softer flavor.  The alcohol is hardly detectable.

Pale, amber coloring with an enormous, bright white foam head.  The bubbles are channeling up to the surface beautifully from the bottom of my tulip glass.  Semi-sweet banana aromas are complimented by some fresh bread and yeast.  Initial sensation on the tongue is rather bitter, but it then mellows out on the palate with the softer banana sensations.  A nice walnutty smack noticed toward the finish.  Not overly complex, but an overall well rounded, tasty brew.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a corsendnk goblet. lots of carbonation in this one with a big white head that quickly dissipates and leaves a nice white lacing around the glass. still lots of bubbles. nose of spice, bananas, wheat, caramel;  and yeast. more spicey yeast, bananas, and alcohol dominate the flavor. not terribly exciting for the style, but i could still see this being refreshing on a hot summers day. the proper glassware for this one almost overshadows the brew inside it.

wow. Been a while since i¬íve been struck by such a decent brew.Warmed to around 7 celcius. Pours loverly honey gold with brilliant clarity. Lots of carb. Like a bloody whirlpool. Nice big white head that races and stops right on point in this St Bernardus glass. Nose is a slight wheat and citric and spice. Taste is a pleasant yeast, milked honeydew, banana nut bread and vanilla. Hops make their way via the 8% alchohol, but non offensive, and no real burn.  Absolutely delightful! Ive got to stock this stuff and Id love to try it on draft.

Pours medium gold with yellow head.  Aroma is earthy, banana bready, alcohol, floral, and a little metallic.  Some caramel and vanilla in flavor.  Alcohol pretty dominant for 8%, almost hot on the way down.  Lots of carbonation at first, but after a few minutes it tames down and is a pretty smooth tripel.
Golden, dark yellow pour.  Very thick head.  Sweet, yeasty banana aroma.  Banana flavor increases in the body.  Warming alcohol finish.

On Tap @ SHARP EDGE...I found this to be a pretty good tripel...maybe it¬ís that I¬íve been trying more, but I¬íve been having some good luck with tripels recently.  This beer had a huge gummy head and a great blond/golden color.  Smelled a bit of yeast, lots of fruit, and spice.  This beer tasted very well balanced...between the fruit and alcohol...and a decent amount of malt and hops character for a belgian (at least I think so).  Mputhfeel was smooth ,wet, and dry...very refreshing...kind of like a summertime tripel.

750ml bottle. Pours a hazy golden, with a significant head. Aroma rich with citrus and apple notes. The mouthfeel is enhanced by the addition of oats, which lends a distinct creaminess. Complex flavor profile with hints of honey, fruit, and caramel. A very well-balanced and delicious Tripel, one of my faves.

Draft.  Pours a light amber with a huge white fizzy head that left good lacing.  The arome is very fruity, maybe some apple, banana, some citrus.  The flavor was excellent.  Belgian spices, citrus, with a touch of hops.  Simply excellent.

Bottled, 750ml. Date reads 12/04/07.   Pours an almost murky light copper color with a big, white, frothy head.  Yeasty aroma with some fruit notes; banana, lemon and apple.  VERY effervescent.  Apples and apricot flavor along with some yeast.  Noticeable alcohol warmth.

Quite entranced by the obscenely big tulip glass, I began drinking this one a few years back without realising I had never stopped to rate it. Quite hard to get a hold of in 2003, it seems to be everywhere now losing a little of its charm in the process. Poured a year old bottle into it¬ís own glass, quite cool to meet the hot summer we are currently having. Huge head rose to the brim of the glass before dying back to a spider¬ís web of white froth. The beer itself a brilliant orange, the same hue as lucozade, with a charge of ultra fine bubbles rising up to atmosphere. Summery fruits dominate the aroma like pears, cantaloupe, pineapple and grapefruit, all tossed together in a juicy fruit salad. Lighter notes of lemon soda just seem to top it off. Quite sweet in the mouth on the first sip, but this dies off so quickly into a tangy and slightly drying back end with a touch of white rum coming in late. Strong notes of sweetened orange juice, feint lemon and lime, clean rye and wheat flavours, and a hint of orange peel mingle with degrees of success on the tongue before finishing quite short and crisp in the swallow. Light on the tongue, not thin in body but leaning towards it, yet surprisingly generous in flavour, this is a unique beer that doesn¬ít carry the normal qualities of it¬ís style. A Summer quencher it is, but it may just fail in the cooler months against the more in-your-face Tripels. Otherwise its quite nice!!! (33cL, 14/09/06, Int¬íl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2006 33 cl bottle, ¬íbbe¬í Jan 07. Pours a light amber, crystal clear body topped with an airy head with rough bubbles.  Yeasty and wheaty scent; quite perfumed, revealing a candy-like sweetness and an earthy aroma in the background. Complex sweet-tart taste with malty, juicy and spicy components hunting each other around. The taste of an aged example is more rounded and coarse, though, with malts becoming more prominent. Very ethereal hoppy finish. Viscous texture.
Bottle, 33cl.  Had a nice golden color pour with a long lasting head.  A little fruity and yeasty.  I enjoyed it.
A superb tripel. A nice white head and a lemony flavour that is perfectly complemented by a hoppy feel and a warm palate from the wheat.

My god... I love this beer, I think I love it because well, it¬ís a brilliant citrusy tripel, and perhaps because it took me by surprise, I hadn¬ít read anything about this one before enjoying a glass of it at my local brew pub.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2006 on tap poured poured a copperish golden color, aroma of citrusy fruits, hops and belgian style spices, flavor was oh so smooth, hop bitterness up front that melts away quickly into its lemony citrus and spicey flavor finishing crisp and clean with some dryness, this brew has a decent body, just a perfect mix.

This dark yellow bodied beer creates a thick, large, three-dimensional head that leaves a delicate lace.
Lemony aroma. 
Ligtly sweet flavor balances out with a dryness as it moves towards the finish.

Pours clear amber with a thick white head that leaves enticing lacing. Aromas of yeast and hops with sweet smells of red fruits such as strawberries and blackcurrant, as well as apricot and coriander. Slightly bitter at first, but the bitterness subsides with saliva and reveals malts ranging from dark chocolate to peanut butter. Aftertaste is pleasantly bitter. A very drinkable yet aromatic beer.
[bottle from dorsvlegel] Aroma:apricot, coriander, spice, gooseberry. full bodied, dry peppery finish. i think i would have rated this higher if i was a big tripel fan, but still an excellent beer.

Bottled. Pours a medium golden color. Big foamy head. Looks highly carbonated. Strong, slightly sweet yeasty aroma. A little spiciness and maybe a little alcohol. Grainy flavor with a taste of alcohol. A little sweetness to go along with the yeast and spice. Good, but it is a little to alcohol flavored.

(12.31.05) 11.2 oz brown bottle purchased from DiCarlo¬ís, Mundelein, IL.  8% ABV. Bottle label states that beer should be consumed before 12.07.07. Light yellow Belgium ale having a large long-lasting white head with good lacing. Good carbonation. Fruity aroma.  Medium bodied that starts dry with light malt sweetness and light fruity notes. Very flavorful. Finishes dry with pleasant malt aftertaste.  Nice tasty Belgium golden ale.
Bottle says drink by Nov 4, 06. Poured into a tulip with a massive amount of white, fluffy head. Nice, gold color.  Malty nose.   Dry malty burn with a sweet, hop finish. Very fizzy.  Quite nice.

For someone just trying out the Belgiums, this one hit me kinda strong at first. I was really impressed with the pour. Carmel in color but the head was perfect and never went away. A full 3/4 to 1 inch thick!!!

I could smell the fruitiness of apples, I think? But, I must have tried too hard to pull some smell out as I had a hard time getting anything after the initial sniff. The taste hit me hard in the beginning with the taste of alcohol, but I was acclamated after a few sips, and it became rather enjoyable. Lifting it to my mouth (repeatably) I start to inhale and smell the fruit and spice.

Drinking it from a 750mL bottle and poured into my favorite snifter, I will enjoy this for the remainder of the Rose Bowl game.

18 November 2005, Bottled Best Before Oct 06:

Appearance is a little misty (poured the whole bottle in), pale golden yellow colour, white diminishing pillowy head, no lacing. Aroma of sweet spicy fruit (bananas, pears?) and belgian yeast. Flavour is refreshing, spicy, fruity and grainy with a warming finish and a bit of alcohol. Juicy on the palate. Overall rather drinkable.

11.2 oz bottle. Yellow-orange color, BIG white, rocky head. Yeasty nose, with some spiceness and some light citrus. Just a touch of coriander. Flavor is slightly sweet, malty and yeasty. Honey notes. Finish is pretty smooth, hangs just a bit. A pretty good tripel.

Bottle. Wonderful hazy blond body with moderate carbonation and a thick white frothy head. Very pleasant hoppy/yeasty aroma with notes of citrus, coriander and spices. Alcohol is pretty well hidden. Delightful and very well malty/hoppy taste with yeasty, citrusy and herbal hints. It ends with a sharp and warming bittersweet finish. Outstanding Tripel. Thank you so much PrimeMinister for that long-awaited sample. Excellent choice for a 700th rating!

Bright, bright orange color, big lasting head, cloudy. Nose citrusy, orange and lime, understated but pleasant. Flavor also "light", sweet, malty but extremely nice, honey and almonds and oranges and vanilla. Finish smooth, sweet, short.
Bottle 330ml: Appearence: Golden straw color with small head. Aroma: coriander, citrus, spice. Flavor: fruits, hops, sweet.  Thank JoeMcPhee.

Aroma is spicy with pepper, coriander, lemon grass and lots of banana yeasty character.  Straw yellow, cloudy with a huge white head that thins.  Lots of banana in the flavor with  more of the corander spice.  Very hot with some noticeable alcohol.  Very crisp  and dry but it still manages to stay sweet.  Thanks to malachi for sharing.

Pours golden, almost like an apple juice.  The intial aroma contained corriander and spice with a small hint of fruitiness.  The taste was almost all fruit - bananas and cherries being the strongest - shortly followed by hints of toffee and burnt toast.  It causes a unique burning sensation in the nostrils.  Excellent choice for a tasting session.

Poured an effervescent golden with a fizzy white head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma of apples, pears, cinnamon, dark fruits.  Taste is sweet and fruity with pears, cloves, some herbal hoppy flavors.  Body is light, fizzy, and evanesces quickly, leaving behind just a touch of dryness in the mouth.  Overall a light, pleasant tripel.
This one has get a very nice spicy aroma. Very cloudy orange coloured. Smooth wheaty taste, a bit fresh. Maybe a hint of banana. Very nice.
Bottle 0,33 L. Frothy white excellent head. Yellow cloudy colour. Lots of citrusaroma. Powerfull tripel taste. Long finish. Very nice palate.
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2005 It had a strong wheat taste and the carbonation came across as very strong. It was like drinking alka-seltzer. Cheers !!!

Bottle.  Illegible notes.  Got pretty wrecked and will need to rerate for more details.  What it says is (I think):" nice spice cumin Louie(?) sweet orchard.  I remember enjoying it greatly and I was with it enough to do the numbers at least...rerate is a good excuse to buy another one, cause this is real nice as best I remember, but I don¬ít remember well enough.  Better drink another!

Bottle (330ml).  My 700th rating.  Poured clear bubbly gold with a massive foamy-rocky white head.  Tons of funky coriander and pungent spices, banana, alcohol, lightly roasty-sugary malt, even holly (how Christmasy).  Taste actually has light hop bitterness to follow the promise of the nose, plus a bit of nice aged white wine - solid.  Mouthfeel is moderately carbonated, almost sugary, gently complex, not sweet at all.  Very nice - almost resiny - much more "sophisticated" than some tripels - not as good, but classier, eh?

From the bottle, this beer pours a clear,  dark gold with a massive, lasting head that leaves behind nice lacing. The armoa is a veritable corriander bomb with supporting hoppy notes of grass and citrus and minor aromas of malty horseblanket and cellar. The flavor starts off sweet and ends with a hoppy, clean, slightly bitter finish. The palate is fizzy, light and drinkable. I found this beer quite enjoyable.

Bottle. Poured a clear amber with a huge frothy white head that was lasting and produced good lacing. Good citrus and yeast aroma. Medium to full body with fizzy carbonation. Heavy bitter sweet flavor with and average finish.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2007 A huge and somehow brown head, great aromas of pepper, herbs, very flowerish taste. Very complex beer.
Drink it next to a piece of french cheese, a "quiche" or a course with melted cheese on top.

Bottle poured a hazy yellow with a huge thick white head and thin lacing.
Aroma is crisp with light yeast and lemon.
Flavor is yeasty with grass and fruit with a tangy alcohol finish.
A beer with a very nice grainy taste. It¬ís pretty fizzy though. The appearance of the bottle itself is pretty nice too. Overall a very nice golden coloured beer

(bottle) Light hazy golden colour with a huge foamy white head. Sweet grainy malty nose, slightly toasted with peach and citrus and a touch of coriander and alcohol. Sweet flavour, medium to full body, medium carbonation. Sweet toastmalty and fruity taste, sweetbitter and spicy finish with a touch of rose(-perfume). Very good, but not the perfect Triple.

I heard a lot of good things about this tripel before I tried it, and can easily say they were all true.  Pours clear gold with a very light head.  Lots of carbonation.  Aroma is sweet and fruity, with scents of straw and sugar.  The taste is so clean and light, it almost feels like it does not touch your tongue.  Sweet and slightly fruity that turns to citrus and spice.  A near perfect beer.
This is a great beer. The caramelised taste of that beer is probably unique and the beautoful glass makes it even more special

Sampled in a Tripel Karmeliet tulip glass.  Pours a crisp gold with a generous white head.  Smells grassy with elements of straw, sugar, lemons, cookie dough, coriander and clove.  Taste is initially sweet with coriander dominating.  Brilliant earthy notes soon follow.  Mouthfeel is viscous and sugary.  Finish has a hint of a peppery bite and some nice tingly elements.  Alcohol is well hidden and not detectable.  While somewhat lacking on the hoppy side of things, this is still a fine beer.

This beer was consumed to celebrate the completion of my ethics term paper. My anticipation of this beer has been building for hours. Best before 4/11/06. 
Pours golden with the biggest foamy white head I‚Äôve ever witnessed. Aroma of delicate fruity esters: honey, flowers, citrus, peaches, and alcohol. Taste is a slow fade from lightly sweet to lightly dry.  Alcohol is noticable, but well balanced by spicy yeast. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lush carbonation.  The alcohol and slightly dry finish make this beer feel especially light-bodied. This is certainly one of the world‚Äôs greatest beers.
705 ml bottle.This beer poured out blond and with a huge head.The taste was hoppy,citrusy and similar to Duvel.This was a very good tripel.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2010 Blond and clear yellow colour, white head that quickly disappears. Arom nice fruits, citrus. Long lasting head.

Taste with notes of elderberry, wheat malt. Long taste in mouth.

One of the first beers I rated, and I had been looking forward to taste it again for a long time, and wasn¬¥t disappointed at all. Wasn¬¥t as flowery as I remember, but it was an older beer, but such a nice beer. I didn¬¥t find any reason to change the ratings. Still the best tripple I¬¥ve tried.

My 300th rating deserved to be something special. This tripel pours dirty blonde and fizzy with a pillowy uneven head. Lots to smell here: wheaty, yeasty, citrus oil, vanilla cookie, sweet spices.... it seems to transform as you drink it! All the flavours to match, but with a bigger wheat backbone on the palate. For a tripel this is fresh and strangely light despite the high alcohol, this is a terrific beer for a special occasion (too expensive to drink regularly-- $9.00 per bottle in my local bottle shop).
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Delicious fresh aroma reminds me of hay, caramel and sweet fruits. Colour is a little bit too pale and is bordering on hazy. Carbonation bubbles appears to be rather big and the head is long lasting but uneven. There is a good balance between sweetness and bitterness and the wheat malt is clearly noticeable, but with little bit of citrus to add freshness. You notice the alcohol but it is not excessive, and with long refreshing and a little dry aftertaste, this is the triple of choice!

Dark gold in colour with lots of carbonation. Aromas of banana, mild citrus, mild bready malts, and a touch of alcohol. The flavors begin somewhat malty and sweet, but quickly evolve into a pleasing melange of spices and fruit. The finish is rather clean, making it very easy to drink. Very drinkable stuff and extremely well made.

Pours golden with a quickly dissipating white head - good lacing.  Lots of fruit and floral hops in the aroma - banana, lemon, orange, vanilla, spices, bread.  Has a good fruity taste that is similar to a hefeweizen.  Flavor is sweet but not overly so, crisp, spicy, and slightly bitter.  Has a caramel malt taste that balances the floral hops well.  Good beer, but not as complex as some of the better belgians.

33cl bottle. poured hzy golden-orange with a thick frothy white head. Fruit, floral aroma. Sweet fruity malts make this beer go down smoth. A little bit of spice keeps it insteresting. a hint of alcohol in the finsh tops it off perfectly. superb.
On tap at the Irish Bistro.  Golden with a white foamy head.  Light fruits on the nose, the taste follows along with vanilla, yeast and pears.  A good offering.

Poured with average sized frothy white head.  Head was mostly diminishing.  Body is very clear gold color.  Nose is of grain, citrus, and hops.  Initial flavor is sweet and and finish is sharp, acidic and bitter and dry with an alcoholic bite .  I do sense some coriander/clove/spicy notes in there.  Finish doesn¬ít last too long.  This is a very interesting beer.  It¬ís amazing how much this beer changes from the time you take a sip into your mouth to the finish.  I am not normally a huge fan of tripels, but I really enjoy this one!

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2010 Sampled on draft at the Sharp Edge Beer Emporium this beer poured a dark golden color with a large fluffy white head that produced decent lacing. The aroma was sweet tangy malts, pear, grape with a lightly yeasty undertone.  The flavor is very sweet with nice light malts, candied pear, apricots, yeast, and light dry spice that I am unable to identify. There is a mild alcohol burn. Fairly full bodied.
(Bottle) What a wonderful tripple, the best I¬íve tasted so far! Pours golden amber, with white fizzy head. Notes of spices (coriander) and citrus/lemon. Dry mouthfeel, and well balances bitterness.

Poured from the bottle this beer is a nice golden color with a fizzy head. Aroma is amazing lemon grass with fruity tones and yeasty breads. Flavor is smooth with touches of wheat, lemon, pepper spcies with some grassines and plenty of natural fizz. Mouthfeel is also fizzy but still smooth with little to no burn and the alcohol is well blended. Excellent beer.
On tap (!!!) in cafe Delibere, Leuven. Golden colour, white head. Fruity and floral aroma. Soft and easy to drink, no particular dominating flavour. Pleasing mouthfeel. Alcohol is well-hidden.

No#60. Iv seen this on the best in scotland list and always wanted to try it, but never found it in scotland, so here goes. Aroma is fresh with appley, fruit salad and dried apricots making a delicious aroma. Taste is also fresh and fruity goodness which seems really well balanced for a triple. This is what i would want a triple to always be like, however few live up to be this good.
Good golden triple. Fruity. Although 8%, you don¬ít notice te taste of alcohol too much (like some other triples).

Aroma:Coriander,orange,wheath....
Appearance:Oran gold,light head...
Flavor:citrus,fruit,very spicy.....
Good beer

11.2 oz bottle @saucer:  pours a nice gloden hue with a white head.  aroma is of citrus/lemon, hints of malt and lots of wheat/yeasty/breadiness.  citrusy malty falvors up front followed byt some yeast bready flavors. a little bland to me, i wasnt very impressed with this beer being rated the 3rd best tripel on this site.
Tap at maproom. A bit peppery and sweet. Taste is pretty alcoholic. Gold color, not super dry. Decent, but not amazing.

After this brewery¬ís sublime Pauwel Kwak, I had been hoping for a Tripel as good as or better than the wonderful Brugse Tripel. In the event this was a terrible disappointment. Colour was cloudy gold with a large white head. Aroma and Taste both seemed indeterminate and dull. A bit of sourness and a touch of dryness, but  none of the other promised delights.

33cL bottle.  Well, I should say that my current sample is from a 33cL bottle.  Pours like a darker ginger ale.  Quick head that¬ís gone in a flash.  Spicy (clove and corriander) and yeasty aroma.  Very floral and sweet (honey and caramel) as well.  Mouthfeel is rather dry, spicy and astringent, but sweet and smooth at the same time.  Aspects of floral hops, granny smith apples, more honey and more caramel  and a ton of peppery spices in the flavor.  I remember a few samples from a 750 to be a little lighter and fluffier in the mouthfeel.  Either way, it goes down smooth, sweet (not cloying) and dry.  As far as I¬ím concerned, this is the measuring stick for all other tripels.

CLoudy golden color with a creamy white head that quickly diminishes.  Aroma of a witiber with quite a bit of spice.  Fairly dry finish with just a bit of bitterness.  not a lot in the hop department.  A fairly subdued tripel, but it is nice and smooth and easy drinking.

I remember loving this on draft but out of a bottle was just so-so in comparison...
Appears a light hazy gold with a small white cap that holds and fades out leaving a decent lace.
Smell is subtle with a touch of honey, peach, flowers, grainy husklike grassiness.
Taste is again, subtle, as is the aroma. Good but not knocking my socks off.
Mouthfeel is ok. A tad sticky and gummy in the mouth with mild sweetness and a dry finish.
Drinkability is good but after following a Golden Monkey with this, I was let down a bit. I remember raving about this on draft and this killed it for me a bit. Maybe it was the bottle?
Superb tripel. It¬ís got a great fruity aroma and taste. You almost forget the 8% ABV. One of the best tripels...
Tap at the Map Room.  Large head atop a dark and slightly hazy yellow.  Sweet malts, Belgian yeast, light fruits, mild spice, a bit of dryness, just a lot of subtle stuff going on.  Tasty.

Light a little hazy in the color with a mountain of a head.  Has an aroma of floral hops, spices in the nose, pleasant but not overbearing.  Smooth, a little creamy in the flavor.  Semi-sweet, fruit trys to make an impression. Finishes a little dry somewhat bitter.  A warming effect arises at the very end with hints of fruit, peaches? Nice beer but it has  stages many up and down. One minute this beer can be outstanding then just average.

Pours clear pale orange/amber with a large, dense head. There¬ís a screw of bubbles rising in the middle of the glass¬óthat, with the head, looks a lot like a mushroom cloud. Honey, bread, a little sourness, and a peppery spiciness in the aroma. Feels and tastes like a loaf of bread at the beginning. The middle is peppery, and it ends on a floral note, backed by honey. No perceptible alcohol. Excellent. Possibly better than Allagash¬ís Tripel.
I love this beer.  One of my absolute favorites.  Beautiful golden color.  Snow white head.  Makes you feel warm after a couple.  The taste is simply oustanding.
An awesome tripel, nothing irregular for a belgian tripel, just a very good beer.

Huge white head.  Light golden honey color.
Strong wheat grainy nose.  Heavy citrus bitter taste.  There is a floral citrus component in the taste. Close in taste to the Bayerischer Bahnhof Original Leipziger Gose
simply a great beer. nice aroma. yeast flavor is great, but still somewhat lighter.close to perfection in a tripel.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2006 amazing aroma.  sweet fruits,, citrus fruits, and spices.  gold color.  huge foamy head. tastes like a belgian white and a tripel in one.  huge yeast chunks floating around.  cloudy.  light body with tons of flavor.  yeast, coriander, marshmallows, vanilla, and hops.  excellent!

Bottle conditioned, from Sainsburys. Gold, excellent lasting fluffy white head and soft but insistent condition. Big spicy aroma with hints of corriander, pepper, grain, floral honey and faint butterscotch. Soft and spritzy in the mouth with a solid sweet honeyed graininess, hints of bread and a gently spiced note, although less like the corriander I got in the nose and some warming pepper and alcohol notes. Finish is sweet and slightly spicy, with a gentle perfumed note, some breadiness and a slight dry bitterness. Up there with Gouden Carolus Triple as one of the best Tripels IMHO.
Citrusy (lemon / orange) and spicy (pepper - coriander¬Ö) and earthy (hops - floral) all balance beautifully.  Velvety mouthfeel.  Wamring and soothing to drink.  Exceptionally enjoyable!

Bottle, 33cl. Fabulous this one! Golden colour. It has a strong effervescence and a huge and beautiful white head, with a nice lacing. The aroma is fruity, with notes of spices and malt. Flavour is smooth and a little sweet, everything very well balanced. Alcohol noticeable but not overwhelming, all completed with a dry finish. Superb!

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 Bottle 33cl. Brown and not the version that can be seen on the photo. Huge white head and hazy golden color. Fruit aromas and flavour, mostly citric. I don¬ít have a good tripel experience but this one is the best so far.

on tap at the maproom in its own glass.  taste was sweeter than other tripels i have had.  this is a very fruity and alcoholic beer, but is still quite smooth. not a dry enough finish for my tastes, but still excellent.
Beautiful cloudy, golden color. Medium white head. Rich aroma: fruit (peach?), floral, and yeast. Great combination of malty, sweet and dry flavor with fruit and spice. Really outstanding tripel.

Classic Tripel.  330 ml brown bottle.  Aromas of citrus fruit and more lemon.  Flavors were similar.  Very dry.  Beautiful hazy golden color with a huge foamy head.  I am not a tripel fan, but this was pretty good.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2005 Pours a brilliantly clear, incredibly well carbonated, full gold color with a frothy, rocky, light tan head.  The aroma is spicy with notes of sharp ginger, vanilla, clove, tart pear, plus earthy spices like coriander and grains of paradise.  The aroma is quite enticing and zippy.  The taste is sweet up front and actually get a bit sweeter as the beer moves across my tongue.  The high carbonation levels cause it to dance across my tongue and helps to offset the sweetness.  The spicy, herbal, astringent character of this beer also helps to offset the sweetness.  This beer has notes of orange peel, ginger, pepper, and a bit of cardamom and clove.  This beer is quite tasty, but would be that much better if it was not quite so sweet.

<font size=-4>Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson, AZ<font size=-1>

750 ml bottle from local liquor store.  Pours hazy dark golden with a huge fluffy white head that diminishes slowly.  Aroma is nice and citrus fruity orange and lemon along with yeast and a nice coriander spice.  Flavor is wow, complex, again lots of citrus notes, pineapple, sourdough breadiness with hints of hearty grains and a pleasant hop bite in the finish.  Medium body and assertive carbonation.

Pours a perfect golden honey hue.  Lasting, pillowy off whitish head.  The aroma here is quite interesting.  Sweet grain, oat, strawberry, apricot/peach, cream of wheat, leather, citrus, pepper, mint, floral, mango/pineapple, tomato...I dont know, maybe im overdoing it...Its just amazing.  Anyways...Soft, balanced palate.  Great light fruit, very peach, firm malt.  Perfect mouthfeel, steady carbonation, perfect balance.  Im quite impressed.  Finishing with a subtle dryness and great finesse.  There are some great possibilities for food with this one...It unfortunate this was my first time trying this!

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2006 Re-rate 1/16/06: A totally different experience this time.  A lovely, creamy triple with some nuttiness.  This experience was amongst the best I¬íve had with a Tripel.  Appearance was completely more pleasing than with the originally-reviewed bottle.  I think my first rating was of a bad bottle.


Old rating (3.4) and review:

Rated "blind" in separate notepad prior to seeing RateBeer averages, as it should be.

Highly acidic and/or alcoholic.  I was expecting creamy given the style, but got bitingly alcoholic.  Head is fizzy and diminishes to half foam layer, half no foam at all.  The semi-clear yellow, not cloudy, may be a tip-off to its not being creamy.  Aroma hard to pick up.  Very gassy, bubbly, lots of carbonation.  There are other Tripels I¬íll go for over this.  Good for a beer; disappointing for a Tripel.  7/10.

Added after entering the above in Ratebeer (no change in rating, though): grassy and dry.

Wow - what a beer!  Had this on tap at  BXL Belgian Cafe in NYC, after having a Duvel.  Poured with a proud head.  Pretty beer. Spicy, burnt malt aroma with an alcohol kick.  Less carbonated and somewhat creamier in taste than Duvel, had a teriffic smoky, spicy flavor with hints of vanilla and banana.  Tasted so good and had such a great feel that I finished it way too fast.  Wonderful beer - try it.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Very prominent yeast aroma with light fruits as well; apples and pears.  I taste the alcohol pretty much up front, though others claim it¬ís hidden pretty well.   Some strange spiciness in the finish as well as an alcohol burn.  Good.

Light golden w/ a well laced white head.  Smells of light yeast and a floral perfume hop.  Palate is light well coated but lightly creamy.  Flavor is very floral, hints of yeast bread and bannanna.  Overal a decent beer but not that great.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2010 On tap at Barley John¬ís.  The aroma is huge and floral and perfumey.  The beer pours to a 20k gold with a thin white head with spotty lacing.  The flavor is floral and perfumey.  Light caramel malts.  The palate is light.  Thin and watery. 8, 2, 6, 2, 12 = 3

Tap at Fat Abbey¬ís.  Poured into the gigantor Tripel Karmeliet glass.  A nice hazy straw golden hue.  Creamy white head.  The aroma was oaty, yeasty, cirtusy.  The flavor was nicely yeasty with a lot of tripel characteristics.  Had a caramelly flavor too.  The palate was nicely carbonated and really smooth to drink.  Light hop profile really tied this beer together.  A superb tripel.  8, 3, 7, 4 ,16 = 3.8

750 mL bottle sampled 1 month and 2 weeks past it¬ís best by date.  Delicious.  This beer is quickly becoming a favorite.

(on magnum bottle) Fresh sent of pears and green apples and wet dirt, almost saison-like. Big lasting, white head and a clear corn-yellow colour. Creamy muoth, the esters kicks in some vanilla and peach in the quiite sweet taste. The alcohol warmths nice and quiet in the finish; gives it a applepie-kind of feel.
Lasting carbonated light head.  Good beer in that you sure can not tell it is 8% but I did not taste the great complexity that others have.

Bottle from Sainsburys.  Golden colour with white lasting head. Complex nose of yeast, herb, lemon, orange, lavender.  Slightly sweet in mouth with crystallised fruit but dry herby kicking hop finish.  Lots of bangs for your buck here.

so old-world that if you put this one in the oven for a hour you¬íll get a loaf of hearty bread. 
Awesome thick, chunky waves of smooth malt and banana peels. 
one of my favorites-
UPDATED: JAN 23, 2012 Full-tasting yet refreshing tripel.  At 8%, it¬ís nice and smooth.  Semi-sweet, moreso than I expected, but still very enjoyable.  Grass.
I prefer it on the tap but also in bottle it is always a great moment to drink a tripel Karmeliet. Its taste is unique for a 8¬∞ beer
Bottled(330ml). -the best beer I¬íve tried this year, hazy pale orange coloured, frothy white head, yeasty aroma with few citrus and fruit hints, the alcohol is very well hidden, nice spicy finish
Cloudy blond appearce with an excellent head and lacing.  Active carbonation makes this fruity smooth Tripel go down easy glass after glass.
Dark yellow, quite big bubbly head. Aroma from wheat and yeast, citrus, some fruits and honey. Floral flavor with wheat and yeast. Very carbonated and with a floral finish.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2007 Some fizz continues after pouring for quite a while, maintaining the large creamy white head. The liquid is a mostly clear golden apricot colour, with only a touch of sediment coming in the last drops. The aroma is of spices and wheat, with some lemon coming through, especially on tasting. I can also detect a bit of caramel sweetness as well. Very pleasant in the mouth, and quite a full body with medium levels of sweetness and bitterness. The aftertaste is satisfying, with a long, slightly metallic finish. Deserving of it¬ís high rating.
Golden coloured with small white fluffy head. A aroma and taste of citrus, yeast and a bit of spices. Not bad for a tripel. (Bottle 33cl)
Nice lacing, well carbonated and balanced, crisp finish, nice mix of fruit and spice.  Pretty good.

75cL bottle.  Pours gold with tiny fast rising bubbles and a huge rocky and creamy off-white head that begs you to take out a spoon and eat it, wonderful!  Nice creamy lined lacing.  Yeast (dough) and fruit (bananas) aroma with a light caramel sweetness and wheat malt with oak notes.  Smooth buttery honey yeast and wheat, oat flavor, lightly acidic and bitter with a lasting lightly sweet flavor.  Light fizzy, spicy and lively carbonation medium bodied creamy palate.
The wheatiness isn¬ít overpowering because it¬ís balanced nicely by the fruity flavors.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2008 Pours a cloudy golden orange with a sizeable but short-lived foamy white head. The nose is full of fruits and spices with a noticeable wheaty tone to it. The flavor is complex but not overbearing, it remains easy to drink. I noticed citrus, apple, clove, cherry, pepper and some malty roasted caramel as it moves to the back of your tongue. The mouthfeel is carbonated and airy, sort of foams up in your mouth, but smoothens out to a surprisingly creamy finish. The aftertaste is dry but not very bitter. The alcohol is very well hidden. Perhaps my favorite tripel yet!

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Light copper color with bubbly white head.  Smells of fruit and spice, almost pepperary. Also notes of clove.  Tastes of fruit, especially that of pear.  Very light tasting for a beer with 8%abv which is very well hidden.  Finishes a bit dry.

Light copper, immense pure white head, and lots of lace.  Aroma is very spicy and phenolic with an almost perfume like smell.  Lots of spice as well- coriander, alligator pepper, clove and hints of vanilla.  Flavor is only a little bit sweet, with lots of spicy, phenols and some fruit as it warms.  Less yeasty notes than most other tripels.  Very clean yet complex.  Mostly a dry finish.

Draught, Flying Saucer. Dark orange color, which I wasn¬ít expecting from a Tripel. Almost no head. Brandy like in texture & flavor. Cherry & alcohol flavors are most noticeable. Unusual for a standard Tripel, which I expect to be lighter but still very good..

Drank at this great little pub in Zagreb called Tolkien¬ís from a Tripel Karmeliet tulip. Enormous and thick white head that dissipated at a medium pace. Orange/deep gold colour, and a bit misty. The aroma is stunning, orange, spices (won¬ít elaborate because I don¬ít know their exact english names), dust, yeast, got just a tad unpleasant later, but that didn¬ít detract much from the sheer greatness. The taste was spicy, complex, yeasty. Didn¬ít care for it as much as I thought I would, but I respect it. Hops ? Bitter aftertaste. Alcohol very well hidden. Very, very interesting.

Bottled.
Clear yellow coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of spices (especially juniper) and fruits.
Powerfull sweet flavour with lots of fruits and spices.
I didn¬ít have a notepad with me so I¬ím not going to comment on it from memory.  I¬íll have to rerate this later.

750:  Light hazy golden straw.  Subtle yeasty nose with a hint of peach and orange.  Mid palate is orange and apricot which blossoms into clove and banana in the finish with a tiny touch of hops.  Also slightly creamy.  Interesting brew.   Not my favorite tripel, but this would go very well with banana pudding/foster.

white, incredibly dense, lasting and appetizing head, careful with the pour or you¬íll get overwhelmed with foam.  Under the layer of foam is a nice golden brew. Very soft, pleasing palate, mildly spicy and fruity up front turning bready and satisfying. O really nice surprise as I hadn¬ít even heard of this brew before yesterday. Thanks Ann.
Poured a huge head out of a 330ml bottle, fruity,  spicy, sweet, all very well balanced, easy drinking, no alcohol burn. Very, Very nice brew!
My choice for the summer (although it is a bit strong). Extremely smooth tripel which nice discreete spicyness and full bodied flavour. The flavour is a bit heavy on the sweetness though.

Bottle.  Pleasent suprise.  Ive had this in the cabinet for a month and was afraid it was below expectations.  The bottle is underestimate of the flavor within.  Strong caramel and banana flavor.  An incredibly poweful head, takes a while to pour a glass.  Aroma is incredible.  Taste is slighlty sweet with the caramel flavor pouring through.   EXCELLENT

One of the best tripels I¬íve had. Excellent blending of spices and sweet cake flavors. Hints of banana and some caramel come through as well. I had passed by this beer several times in the store without picking it up. It looked sort of pale and thin through the green bottle. But I am converted! A really great beer.

a sim rate:
This one¬ís an old favourite. The pour is spectacular (highlighted by the glass, of course) and although the head dissapates quickly, it makes for an impressive display! The taste is quite beery but with yeasty, oaty, hopsy, all sorts of this-is-hella-good-for-you flavours... like some sort of healthy breakfast cereal. Nice and tart in the finish. Absolutely lovely!

Bottle. Golden with a firm lasting head. Explosive aromas of white bread, hops, candied oranges and lots of estery notes from the yeast. On the palate the beer is very smooth. Sweet but with very good balance from the bittering hops. Flavour is very fruity. Super tripel!

Bottled.  Honey colored, cloudy (opaque), white head that lasts fully and leaves behind a "wall" of lace, eventually thinning out into wonderful lacework.  In the final glass from the bottle there are a ton of floating objects, both visible and impossible to ignore as you sip in thunk thunk thunk, like pieces of fruit in your smoothie or shake through a straw (if not so severely).   Body is medium and creamy with tons of soft, foamy and a dry finish.  Aroma of cellar and barn filled with a spiciness from which I can only discern clove for certain.  A scent of sugar and fruit.  Unfortunately there is a metallic scent in here as well...how it got into a corked bottle I¬íve no idea.  Flavor is sugary sweet and fruity, pear, apple, and others.  Some lightly sour musk, like cellar and dough, but mostly earthy.  Bitter sweet finish, sugar and spice!  Wood, clove, touch of citrus and an aftertaste dominated by sasafras, licorice and sugar.  Noticable alcoholic warmth, but pleasant and definitely quenching.
Pours cloudy deep yellow. White head with some lacing. Perfume nose, fruity sweet flavour with notes of pear, melon and glue. Thick mouthfeel.

A nice golden color, light but not pale. The white head is tall but not frothy. A very standard sour and fruity Belgian aroma. Very smooth, fruity and refreshing.  The alcohol is masked well, though you will feel it as you consume. A little spice and a tad bitter.  Very good.
This was a very smooth Tripel. Hazy golden in color. Very complex and full of flavor.  Sweat fruit and a hint of carmel.  The aroma was a little weak, but still nice.  I could drink many of these.

Yellow-light brown, rather cloudy beer with a great long lasting white head. The head is easily regenerated by giving it a good swirl. Best enjoyed from a round goblet style glass at about 10¬∫C. Medium-high bitterness well balanced by residual sweetness in the beer. Medium hop flavor and aroma with pronounced citrus notes and fruitiness. Nice body and malt flavor from the 3 grains, barley, wheat and oats. Slightly doughy finish. Excellent example of the great Belgian ales

In the stunningly attractive green painted label 750 ml bottle. The pour is a ripe pear golden color with such an explosive white head that the glass was filled instantly with foam. Aroma is such a pronounced lemony citrus sweetness that nothing else is readily discernable. Good golly it¬ís a smooth drink. I could gulp a whole bathtub of this without thinking about it! I¬íve grown so accustomed to drinking the 10-12 % abv Triples that I had no idea that a lower-test potion like this could be so delightful. I¬ím lovin¬í it, although I do miss the ethanol punch of the stronger triples.

(Bottle 33 cl) Amber-golden, hazy beer with a nice, frothy head. Very soft mouthfeel. Dominated by the malts (this is a 3-grain beer). Some spiciness and citrusy notes with only a faint, late bitterness. Rather complex and indeed very interesting. 250697

Large soft frothy white head on top of a clear light golden body. Spicey lemon aroma. Smooth medium mouthfeel, not real complex but several flavours there, oily, lemons, oats, a hint of peach, sweet malt and a touch of warming alcohol at the end.
I found this beer on Tap at the BXL resturant in NYC.  Yellow collor.  Nice aroma.  Not a lot of head on it.

Clear light orange in color with a head bubbly in texture, gigantic in size, and sticky in its falling.  Very funky nose with bright fruit aromas, whiffs of alcohol, along with a hints of yeast and pepper.  A Tripel just loaded with flavors.  Very complex, funky, farmy, yeasty flavors loaded with fruit flavors.  A sensational beer.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008  This brew was very tasty i enjoyed drinking it immensely.  I thought it was a tasty beer.

Seved in a Tripel Karmeliet tulip glass. Has a caramel, almost banana aroma to it. An amber color with a heavy, frothy white head that practically bursts from the glass  - absolutely beautiful. Moderately sweet with a slightly bitter aftertaste on the back of your tounge. Medium body with a creamy texture and a long finish, lasting minutes after your last sip.

Frothy yet creamy head, beautiful beer! Soap and citrusy nose. Soapy front with a sweet, long finsh. Soft, oily & medium bodied. My local co-op serves this beauty in a 12oz and 750ml. Flying Pie Pizza probably taps a keg now and then.

Brewed with oats (in this puppy, ¬ítripel, means three grains-oats, barley and wheat), this is far more acidic than the usual tripel--which makes it a great change of place for an Acidic Jew like myself. Great glass (chalice with frosted glass on the sides).

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2005 Not a big fan after first try from the bottle, but had it from the tap at Monks Cafe in Philadelphia and my opinion quickly changed.  Very carbonated with a large white foamy head and palate.  Bubbly caramel color with   light, fresh, fruity flavor.  Glad I had the draft.

This is a fun beer.  Something different to be sure.  Really complex malt flavors come through with some yeast in the aroma as well.  Not a lot of hops here.  This is a good one to try to really illustrate some interesting malt characteristics.

Bottle. Very fruity aroma, clove, apricot? Almost clear, golden colour. Big white head, quite creamy. Flavour is dominated by clove and alcohol. Starting off sweetly, turning into an elegant dryness with a little bitter aftertaste. Nice mouthfeel, smooth bubble texture.

On draft @ the taproom. Served in it¬ís own (beautifully designed) Tripel Karmeliet tulip. Lemon, vanilla, spicy aroma. Taste is sweeter than a typical tripel with citrus (lemon) and spicy flavors. Nice "full," clean mouthfeel with a slight bitter, citrus finish. Nice!

Deep aroma when first poured. Settled into a mellower "tripel" aroma: slightly pehenolic, with a good dose of hops and malt. Poured with a creamy head with lots of lace and a slightly cloudy yellow/orange color. Flavor was slightly sweet with a good balance of hops and acidity. Every sip seemed to reveal different flavors: sweetness, malt, acidity, alcohol and a hint of anise. Good carbonation with an effervescent and creamy mouthfeel that lingered for several seconds. Very complex, well balanced and drinkable. Excellent.

Unique orange/gold, hazy color with vivacious bubbling. Hold up to the light and you¬íll get a bit of red colors.  Head is fantastic, looking just like steamed milk on the head of a latte. Bubbles are even and stiff.  Smells of clove, coriander, vanilla, wheat, and cherrywood . Taste is so good and solid with a smooth wheat base throughout. Belgian hops, lemon, drying coriander seed, sweet pit fruit, ginger root,  and pear. A very nice palate. Lacing and stiff head are first rate. Sampled from a 330ml bottle

Satisfying flavoursome Belgian tripel. Poured gold with a huge lasting pillowy head. The aroma is rich with lemony hops, spices, wheat and a whiff of roses. The palate is full and creamy. Spectacular. The flavour is citric and faintly sour, with a dry spiced finish. Carries its 8% abv very well. If it has a flaw, it¬ís the weight of the spices - I found them a little cloying by the end of the bottle. (Bottle)

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2005 25 cl bottle. Excellent caramel and fruit aroma. Beatiful golden body with nice off-white head. Extremely soft yet rich flavor, again caramel and fruit dominating and just enough hop to feel it. Full body with a perfect silky smooth mouthfeel that lamost makes you drink it in 5 minutes... and then order another one!
Without a shred of doubt one of my top 3 favorite beers in the world. It just doesn¬ít get any better than this.

Bottle. This was bright and clear, with a persistent, creamy head. Nose was a dull, yeasty performance, though this improved as the beer warmed. Had a malty finish, which was soft on the palate, and perhaps a little too much carbonation. Back palate was very ¬ílight on¬í and follow through was MIA. This beer was a little ¬íduller¬í than others of this genre, though still a good and solid drink.
Nice grassy pear and green apple nose. Mild flowers and grass palte with good cookie-esque malt body. Very soft and round mouthfeel with a bit of honey and spice. Clean and lively finish.
Another really good belgian strong ale but it doesn¬ít taste special. I certainly don¬ít taste any apples or such as many other ratebeer members do.

Hazy golden straw, fizzy white head.  The nose was a complex blend of pear, banana, orange zest, spicy coriander, and undertones of grassiness.  Flavor kicks off with a sweet dry fruitiness, more pear and spice, and a light hop bitterness at the end.  Medium bodied, fizzy carbonation, dry, fruity sweet finish.  Not bad, but this one is not really my thing...

UPDATED: APR 11, 2005 330 ml. bottle was carefully decanted into a tulip without yeast, revealing a beer with a golden yellow body with an enormous head fed by highly active carbonation.  The nose was fruity with notes of sour apple, pear, and peach.  There were also some earthy yeast tones that didn¬ít quite rise to the level of barnyard funk. 

The taste was dry and sour with some bitterness lingering in the back. I could detect tart flavors like granny smith apples, apricots, and pomegranates.  The dryness was slightly woody and herbal in nature.  There were also some saffron spicy notes here.

The aftertaste was grassy and light with slowly fading spices.  Alcohol was well hidden and did not play much of a role in here.

The beer felt light and airy on the palette and went down quite easily.  Wouldn¬ít mind picking up another one when I am in the mood.

Dense and adherent foam, long persistence and a lot plenty. Decided, and strongly warm taste. Much yielded and complex. Extremely fizz and prickly. Harmonious and full bodied. Long finish with notes of wine cellar and honey.

Hazy orange glow for color, with a booming 2" head that¬ís creamy and foamy.  Some sediment in glass.  Wonderful Belgian lace on the glass as the head begins to fade.  Aroma is predominantly pepper, cloves, wheat and sugar.  Some sourdough characteristics contribute to its mild, pleasing and floral rose smell.  Flavor is pepper, coriander and clove phenols, paired  with a sugary yeast complexion.  Citrus-orange, sweet and spicy.  Traces of lemon grass surface as it warms more.  Aroma also takes on a more lemony smell with amplified scents of alcohol as it warms.  Effervescent; solid body composure.  Alcohol is evident and warming, but isn¬ít distracting or overpowering.  Moderately carbonated, substantial weight, due in large part to the great chewy malt presence.  Finish is mildly sweet and spicy with a smooth hint of bitterness.  All in all, a non-aggressive, pleasing tripel that you¬íd be hard pressed to find anyone who doesn¬ít enjoy it in some capacity.

A light, "clean"-smelling beer. The head is as smooth and flavorful as the beer - I¬íd rather drink just the head of this then most beers. Apple and zest. This is light yet powerful.  It seems simple but only at first...truly great. The fruit flavoring even gets better as the beer warms up.

This beer poured a pale yellow color w/ thin head and lacing.  The aroma and flavor were full of soury fermented light fruit, citrus, flowers, and a hint of honey sweetness.  The mouthfeel was light and carbonated.

2003 or 2004 bottle at Downtown Liquors Trippel Tasting 3/24/05.  Vibrant orange-golden color, good amount of haziness and a fairly well retained off-white head.  Aroma of apricot-skin, light peach esters, a bit of vanilla and some good malt and/or candi sugar.  Flavor is full and round, with plenty of fruit notes but also a bit of light sourness from the wheat.  A good, even, lightly creamy body, which can probably be attributed, in part, to the oats.  Light bubble gum, bananas, vanilla and more ripe, lightly tart fruitiness from the yeast.  Good in all aspects, with a medium to medium-full body, pleasant, low carbonation and a great balance, tending towards the malty side.  Doughy chewiness can be found as it breathes and warms.  A touch of alcohol warmth, like peaches soaked in brandy and cointreau, adds a nice punch to the finish and give further character.  Highly enjoyable for me, love to have more.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2005 From a bottle in a large wine glass. My first ever Tripel, so I may come back and revisit this one. Golden yellow with a slight haze. Small white head which dimished, although the glassware was less than perfect. Fruity aroma with apple dominating, almost cider like. Flavour is sweet and fruity at first with some alcohol kicking in with the reasonably sharp carbonation, and a slightly bitter spicy finish - all very well balanced and smooth. Long pleasant after taste. Is this a beer? Almost like a dry cider with hops added.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2006 From A Bottle.Golden yellow in colour with a lasting medium head,aroma is of bonfire smoke and lemon,
taste is of herbs,spices alcohol and citrus,with a dry lemon finish.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 Drank at cellar temperature. A fuming growth of bubbly white head over a lucious golden amber tan pour. Head diminishes somewhat. Super Sticky thick lacing. Apple and yeast dominate aroma, but fig, pear and seared foie gras bring up the background. Astonishing on the tounge! Tangy caramel with sweet raisins, brandy, and subtle yeast. A little bit of that cheerio flavor. Alcohol appears but only as a warm glow. Palate is sweet, smooth and fulfilling, with a light chewiness. Like nothing I¬íve had recently...
This is kind of rich and delectable. Very Belgian. Warming as the strength goes down the throat, but not heavy or aggressive. I like this.

I have had this before, but never rated it.  The pour is a nice clean orange with a lot of bubbles and a HUGE rocky white head.  As soon as I pulled the cage of this bottle the cork slammed off the ceiling.  Fruity and spicy aroma.  A little peppery.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  The head remains huge throughout.
Bottle.  Golden amber color with big creamy foamy head.  Yesty floral aroma.  Taste is malty with herbal hops and pepper.  Oh man this is good.

This tripel pours with a golden body topped by a thick, sustaining, white head with good lacing.  The aroma spicy with notes of orange zest, a little sweetness and a touch of sourness.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet bitter with pronounced spicy notes and a little orange zest.  Full bodied, aggresive ly tingly on the tongue and slightly warming.
Golden coloured with a Duvel-sized head. Yeasty, fruity citrus aroma. Light, but not thin body. Fruity, dry flavour. The alcohol is noticable, but not in a negative way.

Hazy, deep golden-orange color. Lots of fizz with a durable, thick, creamy white head. Leaves a thick web of lacing as glass is consumed. Luscious complex aromas of lemon, orange, peach and spices with some mild bready yeast emminate from the chalice. The silky smooth, full mouthfeel and texture of this ale is a treat just in itself. Delicate floral, spicy, fruity flavors pleasantly bathe the tongue followed by a crisp, hoppy dry finish. A very complex, yet delicate and classy Belgian Triple. Worth the search.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2006 Beautiful Beer!!
Frothy white head and slightly cloudy pale yellow brew.Sweet citrus aroma ,very nice easy drinking and it hides its alcohol very well the aftertaste is anice hoppy finish .Really good beer,I could drink quite a few of these.

A gigantic thanks to beerhandy for this one.  My last 6 on the way to 1,500 will be stellar beers, starting with this one.  Pours hazy lazy gold with a big, creamy white head and more lace than a 500 pound bride.  Aroma of big light fruit, candi sugar, barnyard, perfumy citrus.  Awesome aroma!  Tastes citrusy, candi sugary, with perfumy floral esters and more fruit as it warms.  Super smooth, citrusy, fruity, highly carbonated finish.  Just a wonderful beer.  As it warms, it acquires a champagny quality.  Perhaps the BEST Belgian beer (definitely one of the best) I have ever had, and that includes the big boys.  I¬íll let you bang my sister for another one of these.

Orange-gold hue, with big foamy head leaving lace on the side of the glass, yeasty, fruity aromas of peaches, oranges and spice, medium bodied, fruity flavors of apricots, oranges, sweet, spiced maybe coriander with a dry and acidic finish
Golden coplour with a big white head. Spicy yeasty lemon aroma and a light sweet fruity taste. Medium to full body and a worm dry finish.
BCA. Tropical fruit spice and yeast aromas. Delicat yet firm body, refreshing with a dry spicy finsih. Effervescence complements rather than competes with the beer.
Sweet yeasty aroma with lemon, peppery, spices. Pours a dirty gold, white foamy head. A gentle spicyness and smooth delivery. A dryish finish and light fruitiness.
Bottled. Malty, slightly yeasty, fruity, orangey aroma, some spiciness. Tastes sweet, fruity, very orangey. Notes of spiciness and maltiness. The best tripel I¬¥ve had, by far.

Cloudy golden-orange coloured beer. Large head, that remains exceptionally well!  Very tempting aroma of citrusfruits, fresh, juicy. A bit sweet in its taste, lightly fruity and spicy. A bit overcarbonated for me, but this is certainly a worldclass tripel.

poured a semi cloudy golden color with a medium head.  aroma of lemon and other citrus tones along with a yeast addition.  The taste is grapefruit sourness with a sweet wheat malt addition and some yeast.  Light moutfeel with good carbonation.   Nice..
Tap.  Orange straw color, with thin to no head. Astringent florals and subtle peppery anise spices stood out from the usual Belgian sweetness to say hello.

i got loads of white head from this tripel even with a super slow pour.although it did look beautiful sitting atop the yellow/copper body.i put my nose up to the frumpy white head a gathered scents of straw,lemon,vanilla,and yeast.after letting the head settle (that left wonderful webbing b.t.w.)i took my first sip.the flavor was dominated by sour grapefruit,then came some straw,yeast,caramel and candy.overall a different trpipel that is very tasty.

2004 75cl bottle champagne POP! Announces the pouring of this great Belgium treat.
Pours deep gold with a white meringue like head. The aromas of honeysuckle and some earthy spiciness come through. Very bubbly on the tongue, sweet cake like flavor
Some yeast and faint spiciness. I would classify it as 8 parts saison(Dupont), 2 parts triple and 1 part sugar. Very drinkable

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2008 Bottled from Sainsbury¬ís in their beer ¬ífestival¬í 2005. OK, I¬íll stop taking the piss out of Sainsburys now, their festival¬ís like Ellen Macarthur, short yet plucky.  This is an outstanding brew, massive pillowy head, incredibly effervescent golden body, ripe banana and wheat nose, a crispness that dessicates its way across your taste buds, a massive sugar hit before the uncomplicated finish; pure gorgeousness.
