Just realised I could buy a three litre bottle of this. Now then, there¬ís a BBQ afternoon to remember/forget!  See This - Buy This

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2008 Re-rate, Jan 28, 2007: Draft at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/chicag Map Room. Bright brass color with a light head. Crispy malt smell. Taste shows thick, syrupy tripel malts. Lots of Belgian sugar, with only mild bitterness. Hews very close to style, which is nice in its own right, I guess.
Original Rating: Feb. 7, 2005:
Corked bottle. Big foaminess on pour. Color is a dark straw, if such a description is possible. A bit of banana ester that threatens to overwhlem the rest of the taste. Then I get a touch zinfandel wine for some reason. Very interesting.

Bottle:  Aroma is floral, citrus, teriyaki, and pepper.  Pours a transparent orangish-gold with a white head with decent retention.   Very sweet up front with lots of banana.  Finishes a little citrus sourness with a small alcohol touch.  A little hops and pepper in the finish which blend well with the light sourness.  Aroma takes a hit from that teriyaki smell.
Wow what a beautiful beer. Has a nice frothy foamy head poured with a golden haze. Has a very flowery, spicy taste to it almost champagne like. Very easy to drink. One of the best triples out there.

33 cl bottle; Huge, puffy, white head on top on a golden slightly hazy ale. Yeasty, spicy, flowery, sweet aroma. Sweet complex flavor with warming alcohol and perfect balancing bitterness. Powerful champagne-like carbonation without being annoying. Maybe a bit too sweet, but otherwise the tripel that any other should be measured against. I love it!

Tasted 21/01/2005.  3L bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits.
Enjoyed this one with TheGrandmaster and Tyrrell as pre-dinner drink at Great India.
Pours a relatively bright gold for a tripel, almost no cloudiness.  Nice temperature, cool but not chilled, means we¬íre giving this a chance to show off its best properties.  Airy white head releases a soft bouquet of malt and wheat with some stone fruit yoghurt from the yeast (apricot, nectarine, peach).  Very smooth medium-bodied mouthfeel with a softer carbonation than I¬íve got from the majority of the tripels I¬íve tried.  The lack of the usual tripel spiciness probably intensifies this smoothness.  Palate is sweetish, but cleans out nicely.  As you¬íd guess, starting the night with an 8% ale really gets the chatter going (but I can¬ít give out extra marks for its social lubricant quality).
Beautiful printed label bottle.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2005 Poured from the 3 litre bottle (yes, the big boy).  Enjoyed with a good curry at the Great India in Wellington, NZ. Sweet, but not as spicy as I was expecting. The wheat flavours come through quite strong. A lacy head holds through the glass.

Pours a  golden color with fine, thin, lacy white head. Nose is yeasty with citrus and malty notes. Complex blend of sweet malts. Cinnamon and fine caramel flavours. Large, full and complex palate. Finishes with pleasant lingering tickle.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2005 This is the " Creme de la Tripel" in my opinion.  A perfect golden color with a large substantial white head that lasts.  Yeast and spice are in the forefront with aroma and taste.  A smooth body, slightly sweet but not cloying as with most tripels.  very nice.

Golden color with a bubbly white head.  Flowery & citrus aroma.  Grapefruit that goes with the aroma.  Candy sugar, dark dried fruits.  Moderate hop bitterness & flower taste.  Full-mouth feeling; tickling carbonation.  Good mouthfeel.

75cl bottle, date rubbed off the cage.  Slightl hazy bronze color.  Nice foamy white head. Cork in the nose initially.  Nice creamy, silky body, highlighted by an earthy cellar character along with some sweet vanilla malt in the finish.  Reminds me of St Druon de Sebourg in its combo of spice and must.  Very enjoyable, I¬íll have to find a smaller uncorked bottle to see if it has the same character.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2005 Pours a cloudy gold with a frothy head. Aromas of apricots and figs. Juicy orange flavor w/ some sweet passion fruit. Grassy styrian goldings. Nice refreshing body.  A little on the sweet side for the style. Need to use a bit more sugar in the boil.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2005 This tripel  pours golden with a great amount of yeasts if poured slowly.  The aroma is dominated by wheat, orange, banana, and malt for the most part.  There is also wine in it.  The taste is basically the same as the aroma with hops.  The sweetness of this beer makes it unique.  The aftertaste is kind of like a wine aftertaste.  A very good tripel indeed.

75cL bottle aged for more than a year.  It has been a while since we have had this but it is not as we remember.  Not that we are complaining!  It is light golden/straw color and a bit hazy.  We thought this beer was sweeter, but maybe the age has done it well.  It has a citrusy, fruity, saison flavor combination going on in it.  Very nice.
Hazy Orange-golden beer with huge white foam. Refreshing nose with touches of fruits, citrus, honey, malts and bisquits. Tingling mouthfeel elegant light fruity afthertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2005 a very nice and mellow beer. beautiful in it¬ís proper glassware. golden, hazy straw colour. smell is effervescent, light, and citrus. very pleasing. somewhat sweet, very fruity with plum, spices (cloves, cinnamon),malt, citrus, and hops being the most noticable. Reminds me very much of a very complex and strong heffe. great flavor but not too complex. foggy with a huge fluffy dense white head. mmm tasty!
Peach, coriander, a little spice.  Alcohol well hidden.  Very nice dessert beer.

Orange murky colour, huge rocky head. Great aroma of banana and bubble gum with a hint of spice. Smooth medium bodied palate. Belgian yeasts and malt dominate, with a mildly sweet taste. I can taste a hint of spice, but not enough to identify it.

Bottle: Poured a clear golden color ale with a huge thick foamy white head with excellent retention. Aroma is quite complex with a mix between candi sugar and good old Belgian yeast. Taste is very refreshing with some spices, candi sugar (well balanced by the way), good malt and finish with the yeast. Carbonation is excellent and body is above average but still not too full. Good interpretation of the style with all the ingredient well balanced.
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2005 Sometimes simple is better.  This stuff, in its lack of complexity, is a very enjoyable brew.  Slight  cinnamon, slight citrus.  Overall, a nice brew.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2010 Bottled, 33cl (BB 10/2006)
Yellow, slightly hazy, color, good creamy white head. Aroma is light: fruity and malty. Oily, sweetish, alcoholic, hoppy. Smooth, carbonated mouthfeel. Gives long warming aftertaste. Decent, not bad but current RB score of 3.9 feels a bit overrated compared to my score :) (5/2/7/3/10 2.7)
Re-rated bottle 33cl (BB 08/2012)
Because of my "bad" rating in 2004, sayravai gave me this bottle as a XMas present and I promised to rerate it. 
Golden brew, a bit murky after yeast added, white head is mostly vanishing. Aroma is fruity with pineapple and peach mixed with notes of pine needles. Medium to full bodied. Palate is oily, good strong malty backbone. The first impression is exotic fruityness: apricot, honey and banana. Hops pick up in the finish. Aftertaste is sweet fruity, backed with some alcohol.
(7/2/7/4/14 3.4)
Pours cloudy golden with a thick fluffy white head. Light fruity nose... some apple included. Real bubbly mouthfeel. Sweet taste with a light touch of hops. A bit simple, but not bad at all.
A very fine nice tasting belgium abbey tripel. Full of taste.

This golden ale pours with a short white head, eliciting a flowery aroma. The flavor is sweet and hoppy, with a slightly bitter herbal finish.  Overall, a satisfying and somewhat unique example of the Tripel style.

Fruity (pears, apricots, berries, orange, lemon), yeasty  and sweet candy sugar in the aroma.  Almost opaque with good clarity lots of persistent carbonation ans fine-bubbled, lasting cover of head.  Flavour contains notes of dough-like yeastiness, plenty of the same fruits as found in the aroma and a very sweet maltiness. Bitterness in the finish takes the edge off.  Very strong carbonation prickles the tongue and the sides of the mouth and brings out all the nuances of flavour in this medium-full bodied beer, but all in all it may be a bit overly gassy for my tastes. Bottle.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2014 (Bottled, 0.33l) Almost opaque, golden color with a small head. Complex-fruity, perfumed, slightly sweet, extremely pleasant aroma (one can find almost anything in this!). Very fruity (apple, orange, banana, strawberry), honeyish, slightly yeasty, spicy, complex flavor. Sugary-malty, medium to full-bodied palate with very well-balanced carbonation. Alcohol slightly present, but feels like an ingredient - not a negative thing. Just an inch too sweet from being the perfect tripel! Awesome! (Bottled, 1.5l, 2004 vintage) A quite different brew at this size - I suppose the bottle had gone slightly bad. Yellowish golden and hazy with a huge head. The aroma is milder, earthy, saison-like, with lemon and lots of moldy cellar. The flavor is also milder with less fruity sweetness, and more yeasty, moldy sourness. Still somewhat sweet, spicy, and a great brew. Should re-rate the big bottle, though.
golden color with a fat lasting head. lemon and yeast aroma. taste is orange and creamy, nice acidic attack on the tongue that opens up the flavors of cantalope and pear that linger.
Bottle. Straw body with a thin foamy head. Notes of spice, bubblegum, banana, and sun tan lotion come through. Soft mouthfeel.
(draft)  Had a head that lasted forever.   Quite a bit blander than other Belgians I¬íve enjoyed - this had a more lagerish taste to it, and no apple taste at all.  Despite that I did like it though.

330cl bottle at Markt NYC.  light yellow clear gold color, medium whitish head.  aroma of capers, mustard, citrus and yeast.  sparkly carbonation, medium body.  flavor is dry, with chardonnay tastes - buttery, creamy, crisp, white grape.  pear and pepper.  finish is dry maltyness.
A very good blonde beer.  Very smooth and palateable.  Has a great fruity aroma along with the slightly fruity taste.  A very balanced Tripel.  Perhaps second only to Chimay Tripel.

Golden, tall white lasting head. Fruity sourish aroma with yeast, citrus. Good carbonation. At first malty sweet flavour, almost prefumy, then som underlying sourness, citrus and coriander, yeast, and finally a touch of hops. Oily palate. Smooth. Hides the ABV very well. Overall mild and well balanced. This could be the perfect tripel...

Spritzy looking orange/tan ale with a spongy  light white head. Aroma of sour orange with vanilla, some wet cardboard and flowers.  Full bodied, sweet with a slight acid finish. Very round and mild on the palate. Quite fruity. Excellent thought a bit sweet for my tastes.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2005 Bottle. The colour is shady orange-gold-beige. The compact firm white foam is almost four fingers thick!

A sour wheat beer and lactose flavour dominates the smell. There are some notes of corn and bitter almonds.

The carbonation is powerful with small bubbles that develop into foam in the mouth.

The taste is quite alcoholic, but there are also are notes of apricot, liquorice, vanilla, diacetyl and lots of sourish flavours and lactose. The aftertaste is almost as complicated with a finishing touch of sour citric fruits.

Those Belgians might be totally nuts, but when it comes to strong brews that resembles of nothing else, look no further!

Gift pack with the Karmeliet glass. Best before 2006. Glass leaves room for as much head as beer. Beer is soft lightly cloudy gold under a mountain of merangue-like foam . A few clumps of ttractive lacing on the glass.  Aroma of alcohol, flowers, grass and melon. Flavour is delicate, light fruit with a soft body and touch of spice and hops in a finish that ends with a sweet farewell.

Picked up at Whole Foods in Austin, TX. Cloudy, light orange murky pour with a thick, frothy white head. Clean, candy sweet sugar and banana aroma with some cloves in the back end. Some yeastiness in the flavor with some banana, and cotton candy sweetness. Slighlty one dimensional - leaning to much to the sweet side. Alcohol hidden well. Good, but not great.
On tap at Summits Wayside Tavern...Pretty standard Belgian fare Full of yeasty character and light fruits like bananna,pear and grapes...nothing special here

pale straw with orange highlights and a thin head. sweet fruit, coriander, apple, pear, white grape, butterd bread. subtle sweetness then orange, ginger,  pear, sweet malt. nice creamy roundness in a fairly dry beer. nice dry finish with no off flavors.  easily drinkable beer.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2005 Excellent! Very drinkable. Off white head that never dissipates all the way, gold color. Floral, hop aroma. Tastes like berries, a little sweet and alcohol completely hidden. 4.7
UPDATE: I bought a second case of this beer, and it is quite different. There is no sediment, when there was a lot before, making it very clear this case, no cloudiness like before. The alcohol is now quite evident. I¬ím not sure if my last batch was more aged or what. It¬ís still good, but not nearly as good as the other case. Also much more on the dry than sweet side. 4.0
Poured amber color.  Aroma of fruits and yeast.  Flavor is sweet apples, bananas, and some pepper.  Mild sour tang on finish.  Meidum body.

Poured a light amber with a thin white head. Banana, grass,  lemon, and light spice on the tongue. Medium bodied mouthfeel. Sweet with lots of citrus on the tongue. A great beer for a style I really don¬ít care for.

Pours golden, with a frothy and substantial head.  Has a kind of sour taste, with lots of citrus notes as well.  Light and refreshing, but strong too.  An interesting and unique beer, definitely worth trying.

NIce Abbey Triple.  Amber color,medium sized lasting white head.  The aroma was citrusy and floral with maybe a spicy note to it.The flavor was fantastic,nicely fruity with a decent malt side light caramel and spicy with some sweet and light sour notes coming on as the brew warms.The finish is and fruity.

Clear darker coloured body with a frothy white head. Aroma of grass, coriander seed, curacao and pepper. Light to Medium-bodied; Nice full-flavoured taste with traditional belgian white characteristics. Overall, very nice-definately one to try! I sampled this beer on 15-May-2004 at the May RB Party in Toronto, Onatrio.

Very very good.  I like the darker Belgian beers a bit better, but this one is deceivingly full in flavor for a blonde.  a nice thick head pours from the bottle. It is certainly fruity, but not overly sweet.  Really nice.
flavor is amazing.  raisins, fruit, peaches, tart cranberries.  good sized creamy head.  seemed fairly carbonated.  aroma is just like the taste.

Best Before 1/1/2007 Ok, now that I have calmed down after my near beheading by the cork from this bottle I can tender my opinion.  Clear sparkling golden light amber with a massive white densely foamy head that lasts forever. The aroma is amazing, pepper, coriander, fruit (peaches/necatrines), herbs, [continue adding adjectives here...]. Seriously there is that much going on. One of the best noses out there. The flavor is almost as good as the aroma, sweet lucious fruity peaches,  definite yeastiness balancing the sweetness. Medium lively body with a fairly dry finish. Does not feel overcarbonated in the mouth which I feared after the cork episode. A damn fine tripel, up there with the Allagash. Definitely need to do a side-by-side with the Allagash and this one.

One of the finest tripels I¬íve tasted so far, a complex taste with fruit, spices
and bitterness. Golden color, white head.

My favourite Belgian beer (which is not saying that much).  Corn and citrus smells.  Golden colour.  Gets better with each sip.  A raspu underpinning finishing off with strog alcohol and then back to corn falvours.

Solidly warming tripel, a bubbly golden color with a huge white head.  Truly a stong citric aroma, lemon and grapefruit.  It¬ís got a fizzed-up mouthfeel as it delivers sweet, spicy flavors.  Strong alcohol presence.  Good clean finish with a tangy feeling left in the mouth.

Effervescent golden beer with a big white head. Aromas of Italian food being prepared...pretty sure it¬ís the beer and not the house but it caught me off guard. Sweet and spicy with a smooth finish. Quite enjoyed this one - cheers Tim and Doug!

Bottle, with cork popping upon opening cage.  Very carbonated, crisp golden color very clear.  Crisp citrusy aroma.  Not too candy sweet,  clean finish, doesn¬ít have high abv taste.  Overall good beer however, have had several better tripels.

Got lemons? Well if you don¬ít here is where you can get the hook up. A golden appearance with a ridiculously large head. A very carbonated beverage this is. Aroma is bananas and lemons. The flavor is very sweet with some lemons and peaches. A bit of a spicy finish. Pretty good just not great.
Cloudy, light golden color with a nice head.  Aside from the extreme sweetness, I detected lemons, bananas, and apples.  Very soapy mouthfeel that I did not enjoy.

Hazy yellow/gold color with a mid size
white head. Sweet bread like aroma with
hints of fruit and spices. Sweet, fruity
flavors(apple and banana mostly) typical of many Belgian tripels. Not bad but a touch too sweet for me. I prefer a
drier tripel.

Phenomenal three grain beer...delicious, with a sweet fruity start that leads delicately into a potent, hoppy, slightly alcohol-flavored finish.  It¬ís hard to stop drinking this beer.  Have had it on tap at Gollem in Amsterdam and it¬ís even better that way!

On tap.Clear golden brew.Stick your nose in the glass,man.apple pie ,fruit sweetness.Hate to sound generic but it has the classic Belgian fruit flavors from the yeast they use but you can¬ít complain.A little thin on the body but not a bad brew.
Hazy golden colour with a quickly disappaiting head. Very decent classic tripel aroma. Nice fruity (banana?) flavour and a fine bubbly palate.
poured a light copper with a white head. aroma citrus (lemon and gapefriut) yeast, apple. flavor wheat came out 1st, lemon,, hint of honey and apple a nice alcohol burn. a good beer
Golden straw color with creamy head.  Aromas of clove adn banana.  Very sweet sharp belgian flaovrs. Creamy mouthfeel.  Overall as a tripel just okay.

Pours a clean hazy pale yellow with a thin head. Sweet apple aromas that are suprisingly light. You can taste the wheat in the beer, the body is light but the flavor is big. Mostly sweet, almost like cotton candy but with a lot of fruit in the background

Great tripel!!! Served in its own glass at Maproom, Chicago.  Golden and light and scary easy drinkability to this one.  Sweet taste and medium mouthfeel, with a nice dry finish to balance the sweet taste.  Had many of these and crawled home.  One note, this is a much better beer on tap than from the bottle where it can be a little too yeasty, unless you prefer this.

Sour smell, like a sour lemon, and I¬ím not wild about it.  Pumkin orange and opaque.  Pours with a foamy head that settles to a medium layer.  Effervescent and active in the mouth. Flavor of spiced oranges. Pleasant finish.  I enjoy it more as it opens up.
MId gold to light orange, slightly cloudy with a white head that lasts well.  Musty/lemony aroma.  Musty flavour with a notable alcohol kick and a dry finish.

33cl bottle tasted alonside Hoegaarden Grand Cru - I found them very similar, but this is just slightly better IMHO. Head bigger and longer lasting than the Grand Cru, similar light orange hazy appearance. Honey, vanilla, pepper and hop flower aroma, full bodied with long hoppy finish.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 Cloudy yellow beer with a thick, lasting white head. Fresh aroma with lemon, coriander, fruits and honey. Lemon and candy flavour with a hint of alcohol. Big almost oily mouthfeel.

Pours a sharp golden orange with strong effervescence and a beautiful fluffy white head. The lace is fine, smooth, yet sticks to the glass. The aroma is fruity, of bubble gum, hints of spices, fresh and full. The taste is smooth and sweet with a well-balanced dry finish. The MF is smooth and soft with a wonderful transition from sweet to dry. 
IMHO: A well balanced triple with no big surprises, and is subtly complex. Karmeliet has a great combination of flavors and smooth transitions.

Bottle from Safeway. Poured a hazy golden colour; extremely lively. Thin but sustained bubbly white head. Aroma is peaches and oranges and honey. Flavour is complex, honey and spices and alcohol and much more. Nice foamy mouthfeel. Very refreshing, very nice; good quality beer.

Although I am not a great fan of Belgian Tripels I did find this a quite pleasant drink.Quite fruity and comlex with lacing that lasts as you work your way down the glass.Not easily avaiable in England but well worth searching for.

Hazy gold color, fine white head, and fortunately poured into it¬ís own particularly shaped glass. Aroma is uplifting, arousing, sensual, jumping with fruitiness, peaches, tangerines, apricots, citrus, lemon, alive with bright, sunny flavors, and a joyful honey/candy sweetness. Absolute happiness results from a mere sip of this glorious brew, growing with each new drip down the lips!
Yeast, also, does some work towards delivering the drinker to Beer Nirvana, creating a warm, bready feeling. Body is somewhat light and buoyant, palate is delicate and delicious. Soft, sweet malt, long and lingering, rewarding finish, always accompanied by a tidy, tasteful dance of hops upon the tongue. Ahhhhhhh!
Unfortunately, this happy ride was all-too brief, for the otherwise unredoubtable pub poured a meager 8 ounces. Geez, guys, I¬íd pay an extra $.50 for another 2 ounces, and willingly, too!

review from draft serving, Bryant-Lake Bowl, January, 2003
Just a beautiful Tripel.  Large, long-lasting head.  Golden color.  Malty, a little fruity, with some nice spice thrown in.  I¬ím a fan.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2006 22 June 2004 - Great head retention, ordinary lacing and golden colour cloudiness. Stunning fruit-fruit malt and some spiceness.  Smooth sweet fruit (stone fruit), huge bubblegum, but could do with more spice complexity for balance. Sweet fizziness and light dissolving mouthfeel.
On tap at the Hop Leaf--Chicago.  Yeast dominates the aroma with accents of spice.   Very smooth mouthfeel. It seems to be a very good representation of the style.
Bottled at the Cellar, St. Andrews. Very pale with huge annoyingly-rocky head. Yeasty spicy aroma, fruity banana taste. Evident hoppiness.

08.15.04  750ml.  Cork took it upon itself to leave the bottle just seconds after I removed the cage but no gushing.  Pours bright, light, blonde; massive head, spotty lacing.  Aromas spicey, some banana, some apple, vanilla; nice alcohol presence on nose; something smells buttery(?).  Nice eff on palate, but also very pleasant and coating and smooth.  Flavors are bright and complex.  At times, esp the finish, this beer reminds me of a wit; it is quite citrus for a tripel, I think.

bottle. pours a hazy golden colour, minimal head leaves silky sheets of lace. one of the greatest aromas ever! sour apples, some banana, and pear...simply incredible. mmm, silky smooth...Tart and fruity with a long yeasty (warming alcohol too) finish.  this is simply a fantastic beer!

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 I¬ím not sure what up w/ the my original rating of this stuff. It just seems dumb and though I¬ím not exactly drinking one of these right at this moment there is one thing I¬íd like to add: What really makes this stand out is the huge spicy, sweet orangey nose.

Original rating: Sampled on tap at the Map Room, this is without a doubt one of the finest tripels I ever had. I spent more time drinking it than I did rating... Just beautiful golden in appearance, big head. Rich, complex flavor with the most thick delicious mouthfeel I can imagine. Cheers!
Pours hazy holden blonde with an overactive head...smells yeasty and sweet with light fruit...tastes very sweet and doughy...fantastic stuff, but leaves a candy sugar aftertaste...

This poured a brilliant gold with a loud, fizzt white head.  Aroma of spiced apples and yeast.  Flavor is very complex, with loads of fruit and yeast as well as bubblegum.  Moderately acidic and tart.  Alcohol is barely noticeable.  Finishes dry.  Tasty!

33cl brown bottle.Poured a hazy amber with huge rocky white head & lots of tiny bubbles rising steadily with uniform striped lacing. Acid ginger beer nose.Nice balanced dry fruity acid flavour.Refreshing fizzy mouthfeel with spicy finish. Excellent.
Nice fruity, spicey flavor typical of most Belgian beers. This was a pretty good one and I didn¬ít taste a hint of the 8% ABV. Good stuff.

mmmmm I love triples and this is pretty good.  Great fruity and bready aromas and the taste is no slouch. I don¬ít have the palte to place it all, but I get wonderful hits of fruit and spice on a yeasty backbone. Thouroughly enjoyable. Thanks Joe.

Draft. Clear amber beer with a thin white head. Yeast and spice aroma, but not that strong. Banana and yeast flavors that are a bit overshadowed by the bubblegum taste. Too sweet and not enough depth.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2012 A range of experience by letting it warm and then evaporate some of its spice over a long dinner. aggressive mouthfeel.Beautiful lacing and honey pale gold. Particular spice wasn¬ít for me but ameloriated by various strong spicey food.
Poured a big fluffy head.  Nice golden color with aroma of yeast, spice and fruit.  Taste had hints of spice and yeast.  Very nice beer.

Bottle Pours a very light pale hazy blonde.  A very agressive white head that left nice lacing.  Aroma is fruity including bananas, apples. Flavour was sweet and a bit spicey.  Cloves, bananas again.  Quite sweet. Nice feel, smooth, carbonation is lively but soft.  Pleasant mild lingering aftertaste.

Bottle: Poured a hazy yellow gold with a large fluffly white head that lasted and laced well. Aroma was slightly medicinal (will benefit from some age I imagine), faint bananas, and strong lillys. Some spice notes. Flavour was dominated by spices and candi sugars. Some banana notes and a finish remeniscent of raisin aroma. Fills the mouth nicely, and has a nice finishing bitterness. Very nice, but could probably do with some time in the bottle to develop further.

Poured a medium, hazy golden/yellow with an averaged sized head. Aromas of citiris (oranges and limes), flowers and spices. Sweetish taste with flowers, spices and citris. Nice smelling and tasting.  I took a chance and bought a case of this before tasting and glad I did (damn PA case laws).
Golden colour with a large white head. Nose is yeasty well spiced with floral hops and alcohol. Flavour is sweet, floral and spiced with a yeasty dry finish.
Apologies but this just didn¬ít do it for me.  Pale yellow with fizzy white head.  Fruit and spice in the nose.  Spumante feel in the mouth.  Flavor was relatively sweet and spicy.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2007 Initial rating of 3.4 sampled from bottle. Sampled again on tap at Lunar Brewing company for the Feb 2007 Ratebeer Chicago Area gathering. Very good. Increased rating to 3.9

Clear golden (poured with out sediment to glass but there was some left in the botle) with a big white head that is quickly discipating. the nose is full of yeast with just a dab of malts to it. The taste is yeasty with a bit of apple skin to it. Not bad but I just cant get into the style.

Bottle shot its cork out when loosening the cage. &nbsp Pours translucent golden, HUGE fluffy white head, copious amounts of carbonation, with super sticky lacing. &nbsp Wonderful aroma of spices, corriander, oranges, lemon zest... quite citrusy. &nbsp Forwardly wheat like, light citrus flavor, with a spritzy mouthfeel. &nbsp Other spices seem to be present, but subtle compared to the citrus. &nbsp Finishes light, with the aformentioned spices and a bit of a malty aftertaste. &nbsp Tasty!
Ooh la la!  Very nice and bright golden color with a medium head.  Aroma is very grainy.  Wheat, spice, malt, and touches of fruit on the mouth.  Splendid little brew!
Orange Coloring. Little Head.  Fruit.yeast..bit of spice? ..wonderfully balanced..Wonderful Tripel..would keep this around to age.

Wow... what can I say?  Wonderful spicy aroma with a hint of allspice, sweet, honeyed flavor with a noted alcohol bite, beautiful golden color, nice mouthfeel.  Should also note almonds and walnuts, apricot overtones and citrus.  Complicated and great.
Golden orange with light head. Mandrain orange and vanilla malt. Orange, citrus, apricot and a creamy mouthfeel. Nice sparkle on the tongue, with a rich yet soft sweetness...one of my favorites
sweet honeydew aroma.  refreshingly sweet, with the taste of apple, honey, and a pleasantly warm and slightly dry finish.  a delicate beer that is easy to appreciate.   rather dainty.

On tap at the Ginger Man in Dallas. A  good example of the style. Has a bright gold color with  a small head. The aroma is alcohol and some sour apples. The taste is bananas, vanilla and some ginger spice.  Nice, but not great.

Piney, citrus aroma with hints of banana and pineapple. Yellow/gold color with off-white, lasting head. First pour is almost all head. Let the bottle breath for a minute or so and be careful with the first pour. Excellent lacing. Moderately sweet, tons of carbonation. This has the mouthfeel of champagne. Belgian wheat taste and high in alcohol. Good but not my favorite style.

Had it on tap. Golden color. Not sure if this is how it was susposed to be, but there was very little carbonation like it was flat. It was very smooth with a spicy and sweet flavor. Lightly bitter and alcoholic.

Golden/honey color, white head. Aroma from yeast, fruit, malt and some honey. Flavor is malty, mild at first, some floral touches. Turns spicy after a while. Finish is bitter and fruity. Complex and very nice.

Light honey colored, bead of pearls white head rims the glass.  Aroma is yeasty, fruity and very sweet.  Flavor is taste alot like a granny smith apple with some sourness and yeast mixed in.  Bubbly mouthfeel, sweet finish.  Very good beer.
Packs an apple flavor all the way through, and yet is not overly sweet.  Nice dry finish with a dark blonde to golden body.  With a decent off white head that last¬ís for a while.

Nice and warm golden color with a creamy and fluffy head.It is a very aromatic beer with good hints off ripe white stonefruits,sweet spice and a little flowery accent.The taste is full fresh and has a lot off body.The afthertaste is smooth and it has a fine freshness.Drink it cold but not too cold.
gold, foamy white head.  perfumy aroma with honey, pepper, peach and alcohol.  cereal and biscuity malt flavours play with the pepper.  spicy orangy finish.  excellent.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2005 Pours a nice amberish gold color with a very impressive white fluffy head. Aroma had a great spice smell also very earthy. Very fruity and sweet with a nice crispy finish. Very smooth with a dry finish.

Cloudy, gold, yellow-gold hue. Nice white lace. Sweet, perfume like aroma, grass and wild rose, light hints of alcohol. Good yeast, soft flower and fruit flavours. Sweet but light enough to be very pleasurable to drink. Nicely done.

Beautiful golden-orange in colour with a huge fluffy white head.  The aroma was very floral, fruity(oranges) with just a touch of alcohol.  Flavour was of oranges, peaches, yeast, apples, some peppery alcohol.  Medium body, smooth.  Finishes with a mild creamy sweetness.

Bright golden-orange colour with a big white head. Absolutely amazing aroma - smoky, spicey, floral and sweet. Flavour starts of sweet and fruity (peach, apricot), and develops into a complex mixture of flural and herbal notes before a dry and slightly boozy finish.

Cloudy gold-amber w/ lots of carbonation. White, billowy head. Yeasty & spicy  aroma of banana, peach, pear, clove, & pepper. Soft, effervescent feel. Creamy, fruity, yeasty, wheaty flavour. Dry, peppery, alcoholic finish.

Cloudy yellow body with a huge foamy white head that lasts throughout. In the nose I am getting a sweet candy fruit aroma. Taste is citrus(oranges) with alcohol noticeable. Slight alcohol taste left in the throat as well. Thanks to TimDoug for this one.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2008 2008-03-01. Pastel yellow with a modest off white head. Floral hoppy aroma, light citrus/tropical notes. Similar hops in the flavour but milder than the aroma. Smooth average to light palate. On tap at Zythos Festival, St. Niklaas 6-7/3/6-7/3/14-15 -3.6

May 2004. Big fluffy white head on a amber coloured body. Nice sweet caramelish flavour with a pit of alcohol peaking out throughout. Sweet maltiness. Seemed a bit simplistic to me, but it would be worth a second visit. Thanks Timdoug. 7/4/8/3/16 - 3.8

Fairly clear golden body with abundant carbonation and a monstrous foamy white Belgian-style head. Orange citrus and spice plus some esters, but not too dominating. Some bubble gum comes through more in the flavor than aroma. Honey is a dominating element in the flavor. More sweetness than I¬íve recognized in other Tripels. Very smooth.

Hoppy spicy nose, junipers. Light sweetness, milk, sugar, pears. Golden amber clear, bit of haze. Foamy white lacing head. Medium-light watery body with high carbonation. Good taste, starts medium sweet. Fruity and sugary, wth light spicy hops. Finish is sweet with nice little bitter, bread pudding, pears. Nice after, semi-sweet and alcoholic. Nutty. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2005 Served in a chalice. Wonderful golden colour, pours with a frothy white head, most of which quickly dissipated. Peppery, perfume, vaguely spicy, slighly fruity, subdued sweetness, delicate sourness and bitterness. A really good tripel. (4.1)
RERATE: Hrmm, this one is odd. Last time I rated it it scored high, but I can¬ít see why now. Sweet tripel, high alcohol presence, touch of spice, some bitterness. Very drinkable (but too carbonated), this is not that remarkable. Average tripel.

Aroma of spices, malts, honey, and wheat. Hazy  color, typical of the style.
Head was white, lacing was exceptional.  

Sweeter than I expected, but not overly.  Deeeelicious Belgian!  Highly recommended.

The citrus sparkle, taste and fragrance of the beer earns it the title of "orange bloosom special". Clean on the palate, sweet and yet lusciously sour on the tongue. The color is that of a mirky pool of summer nectar. You can certainly taste the tradition and craftsmanship. The alcohol is well disguised and the sour dough like yeasty tones concocted to mellow perfection. This is a great southern summer porch sipper.
Yeast, bananna, Orange/Lemon and earthy wheat aroma.  Sweet and wheaty, light on the tounge, citrus and yeast.
Cerveza "3 reales" rubia, suave, con caracter y de sabor afrutado, con segunda fermentacion en su propio envase.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2004 Wow. I had this at Muffuletta on Como Ave. here in Minneapolis. Aromas of pear, wheat, and citrus.  Appearance of a cloudy hefeweizen with no head.  Exceptionally complex and smooth.  Flavors of pear, apple, honey, coriander, citrus, wheat, and malt.      This beer is highly complex with many aromas and flavors.this is outstanding and it is hard to find anything better.

A very good tripel.  A balance of sweetness, yeast, and spices.  Quite a few phenol notes of fruit and bubble gum.  It has an amber/copper hue.  Overall its very nice.  Lacks the flavor complexity of the best tripels, and the palate isn't as dry or alcoholic as it could be.

Exceptionally spicy.  This could easily have been raisin and clove wine for the prevalence of those flavors.  The sweetness makes it hard to drink very much of this beer, but for an isolated taste, it's very refreshing.
(bottle) deep gold with good head. Fruit aroma with some pepper. Flavors are yeast and fruits with some spice/pepper.

On tap served in a Karmeliet tulip at Lucia's in uptown mpls.  Aroma of banana and spices. Taste is of banana, wheat and cloves. A very refreshing and surprisingly light (given abv) beer that is a great match with our 70s spring weather.  Not as full bodied or spicy as other tripels like Allagash or golden monkey, but solid nonethelss.

Honey gold and cloudy, a thick head.  Clovey with sweet bakery yeast in the nose.  The taste is fruity and spicy (again cloves), and results from the three-grain wort and live yeast.  As you empty the glass, you should note the origins of the term "Brusels lace".
Deep golden/light amber color... off-white head, very clear... yeasty, phenolic, bubblegum... outstanding tripel, one of the best in my opinion... slightly sweet, excellent balance, smooth finish

Beautiful deep golden color bordering orange.  Nice light head full of tiny bubbles.  Slight fruity aroma.  Flavor is rich malty and slightly buttery like a nutter butter cookie.  Clean crisp finish covers the alcohol nicely.
Pours a golden hue with a nice sized head with decent lacing.  Nothing special for a triple.  Surprisingly easy to drink with not many flavors coming through.

Keep finding beers that I've had a not rated - cool and annoying at he same time. This has to be one of the best deals around. Slight slant to the sweet side, but so well crafted and with so much flavor that it's no complaint really. Another that is almost too easy for me to drink. Lovely glass as well. Yum.

On the pour:deceivingly plain,pastel plum and cloudy.the head looks real good,small compact white bubbles that cling to the side of the glass,this goes way beyond lacing,sweet fruity/yeasty nose.

On taste:outstanding,spicy start,cloves Cinnamon,and sugar,then vanilla and rotten banana's,onto sweet brandy and orange..I could go on but I think i will just kick back and enjoy it from here,you get the idea...Its good!

body is great,thick,full and coats the pallet on first sip,sweet on swallow and fades into rock candy in seconds.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2004 Re-rate My second pass was an entire 750 in one seating. It was fantastic cold, and held up wonderfully at room temp. Yeasty, doughy and fruity. The carbonation and lacing were astounding, all without leaving a fizzy mouthfeel. Highly recommended.

330 ml bottle, St. Alexandre pub in Quebec City. Sure, Westmalle is the original, but this will be the Tripel by which all others will be judged in my world. Side by side with an Orval, Kasteel (not triples, but highly rated blondes, this was the favorite of all 3 partakers. The appearance and aroma was (strangely) like a great weiss-bier (cloudy, dough-like), but with the floral aroma, and substantial lacing head expected in a beer of this style. Blonde Belgians just don't taste better and finish bettter than this. Lacked the over spiciness of Chimay and the over-dryness of Westmalle and Unibroue (La Fin DuMonde).

Well, this one caught me off gaurd, as after I took the cap and wire off, I set it down, and withing a minute, the cork shot out of it.  Fortunately it didn't spill over very much head.  As for the beer itself, nice glassy golden color with a thicker continuous head.  Aroma is a little bit spicy, close to clove scent, and some fruit notes, like oranges.  Mouthfeel is definite and crisp, but doesnt overpower the flavor withs its bitterness.  FLavor leaves a slight grassy feel on the tongue after its gone down.

Beautful painted bottle.  Pours a hazy honey colored brew with a big persistent head.  Fruity, flowery, spicy bouqet.  Flavor equally complex with lots of fruit and not much malt sweetness.  Dry and kind of tart.

Pours a ever so slightly hazy golden orange with a huge and relentless frothy white head. Strong aroma: yeast and wheaty malt, lots of clove coriander and spice, vanilla; wonderful. Flavor is on the fruity side for a tripel: orange and citrus at first, grapes and white wine, acidic and a little sour. Fruit flavor overwhelms at first, and then a vanilla sweetness with medium body malt backing comes in. Has a long finish that's mostly acidic and sweet, some stickiness. I think I liked it less as I drank more, the sourness (which in other beers I love) just got to me a bit. Otherwise very good. Seems like this would make a good session/summer tripel. Celebrating one year at ratebeer.
Golden colour with big white foamy head, which leaves i nice lacing. Aroma and flavor is very complex, with traces of spices, some sweetness and bitterness. Palate was somewhat light.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2004 (Pizza Port Belgian Beer Party in Carlsbad, CA) Mildly sweet, spicy, yeasty, a little bubble gum going on, and minimally bitter; While it's fairly pleasant, the flavor just seems too thin compared to other tripels; The finish is tangy, but also just doesn¬ít have much flavor; Nose is sweet and spicy; The palate is perhaps on the cloying side with little else to balance it out; Golden color and slightly cloudy; Off white head is kept alive by a signficant amount of carbonation bubbles; Small touches of lacing here and there<HR>(Draft / 330 ml bottle) These two tastings seem much less sweet than in the first tasting; Slight sourness; Very carbonated mouthfeel; Color is golden orange and cloudy; On the pour, the white head is huge and becomes very rocky as it dies down

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2004 Before I get to the beer, the glass may be the best looking Belgiun glass I have seen. OK, forgetting about RateGlass.com, here goes. Big white puffy cloudy head on top of gold color. Had a nice doughy aroma. Inside was pure goodness. Fruity, yeasty, peppery and a mellow sourness all came together to make this excellent. Finish was light pepper and sweet caramel. I doubt there are much better than this.

Pours with a four-fingered white head that fades slowly and leaves a good lace.  Medium carbonation.  Clear golden amber color. Light-medium bodied.  Nose is malty. A different triple - starts flowery sweet; finishes smooth and sweet.  $12.50 for a 4-pak of 330's.

Clear, rich deeper yellow in color. Nice dense off white head. The flavor is more on the sweet side, but also malty. Sweet greater than malty. If you are in the mood for a smooth sweeter tripel this is the brew for you.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2004 Nice clear yellow with a huge rocky head. Aroma of dried peaches and apricot. Flavor is malty with peach, apricot and hints of vanilla.A little alcohol warmth follows. This reminds me a bit of the Adnams brews.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 23, 2006 Very enjoyable beer. Golden copper in color with a nice medium white head. Yeasty.Peppery.  Fruity nose. Really good. Medium body. Great beer.

This is a fantastic beer, and very enjoyable.
Nice golden Copper color with medium white head, great lacing.  Slight sweet fruity nose.  Tastes of ripe fruits, and spice with medium body.

750 mL bottle, snifter.  White bread, toasted grain malt (L); earthy, spicey hops (M); doughy yeast (L).  Very lager-ish aroma.  Body is a medium gold and is crowned by the most magnificent creamy, white, lasting head I've ever seen.  Moderately sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish.  Not nearly as complex or Belgiany as I was expecting.  Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: aesthetically pleasing, but the aroma and flavor didn't meet my expectations.

look at that cool big bottle in the picture! i've only seen it in small bottles, but i'm sure the taste is just as good or better.  i remember reading it's a combo of 3 or 4 grains.  beautiful golden color with huge white foam.  little spice taste with medium mouthfeel.  very drinkable and elegant, a nice alternative to more expensive belgian goldens like duvel or even the stuff from unibroue.  (all of which i think are equally good).
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2004 Amazing Belgian Ale, not much I can say that hasn't been said already. Sweet malty flavour but missing some complexity.

Pours true gold with a fizzy head and streaky lace.  Has a deliciously rich and estery aroma with notes of sweet malt, alcohol and spices.  The body is sweet but its weakness hides the alcohol content.  I was a little disappointed with the lack of complexity, but it's a very pleasant drink nonetheless.

5cl Green bottle, poured into a Orval glass.

Pours a light golden color with a really creamy white head that leaves patchy lacing down the glass.

Smells primarily of banana esters with a hint of cloves.

Tastes a bit watered down, to be honest. Good flavor but rather weak and a little astringent. Cloves are the primary flavor. It's complex, though, with fruit esters. Good but not great.

Mouthfeel is, again, a little too watery for my likes. Drinkability is good as there's nothing objectionable at all. A good tripel, but not great.
Hazy golden appearance, medium white head. Nose is citrus, yeast, mint, malty sweetness. Flavor is citrus, elderflowers, mint, some acidness, malty sweetness again, fresh and light. Well carbonated.

This is a Belgian beer intended to be consumed in a trappist glass. When poured it is a charming saffron color, thick but delicate looking. I was baffled by the amount of fizziness this beer produced... it was almost champagne like. The head was high, frothy and light. This combination of exorbitant fizziness and towering spume was daunting, but the aroma leapt out of the glass and agilely enchanted my olfactory nerves. A tinge of honey haze, gently layered upon deep caramel and oceans of alcohol. Tripel Karmeliet is a hearty beer at 8%, but it wears its obvious wealth as a diaphanous crown. The mouthfeel is an ambiguity, concrete and bubbly. Taste is sandy, a Morroccan beach. An arrogant icewine. Immaculate and subtley echoing finish. I call this one "The Imperial Love Child."

What an awesome triple. Pours a lovely golden hue with a thin sheet of foam that never leaves. Aromas of bubble gum, honey and spices. Great big taste. Bananas, honey, mild hops and somthing almost like white wine. An excellent triple. Glad I have more.

Clear yellow color, with a decent sized head.  Constant bubbles coming from the bottom.  Yeast dominated the aroma, but sweetness as well. Yeast in the taste, but also much more.  Malts, some sugary sweetness.  Hints of alcohol as it warmed.  A very tasty beer.  Sadly the last of my gift pack from Europe, but thanks Sue!

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 Golden colour with typical ¬ítriple¬í aroma and taste of bananas and soapy alcohol.  There is no head to speak of which is somewhat disappointing.  The beer though is very drinkable.  Score 3.4Subsequent rating scored 3.9. Average becomes 3.6

Smells actually a little skunky at first, with some citrus/fruit-aromas; pours with lots of carbonation and a thick, pillowy head; mmm, sweet, slightly spicey, with hints of tropical fruits and oak/wood flavors; a nice floral hoppy presence; finishes a little dry and very refreshing for an 8%'er. Wonderful trip, one of my favorite brews.....

bottled:  a beautiful beer when poured into trappist glass, dirty yellow and hazy. the head was huge and thick, billowed over the glass rim without flowing over.  smell of belgium yeast, wheat, musty.  taste banana , sweet, very sweet and smooth medium bodied on the palate. leaves a tarte aftertaste. sipping beer not drinking.

Pours a golden, straw-colored, honeyish yellow with a big, bold head and ample lacing.

Aroma of sweet apples, pears and spicy cloves.

Big mouthfeel, sweet dextrin with banana and plum fruit esters. Smooth and creamy all the way through.

A very nice tripel which I will elaborate upon when more sober. cheers.

Orange and coriander nose with like a demerara sugar tone. I have two of the "correct" glasses thanks to a special bottle shop, I suspect these help a lot with concentrating the smells.
The glass looks nice and makes the huge head look even bigger... This is what I think a tripel ought to taste like, I admit to not having tasted the ones rated higher than this due to availability (but a few in the same score range I have and don't like anywhere near this) and so I guess I should leave room for hypothetical improvements... the robustness of body like a dark double but with the light spiciness that makes the difference. The palate is absolutely smooth and has no edges that cut at the tongue. I am trying really hard not to give this 100% because I know that there are so many things I haven't tried that I need room to manouevre but I currently can't see anything beating this.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2009 Poured into a Corsendonk tulip.  Very lovely thick white head over a slightly hazy golden pour.  Fluffy and very inviting.  The nose is loaded with sweet perfumy clovey spice.  There is a nice sweet white grape fruitiness and a kiss of black pepper.  Light cinnamon and a bit of sweet doughiness.  Lots of soft apricot and a bit of pear as well.  It had been a long time since I¬íve had this and it is just as good as I recall.  

From a 330 ml bottle, best before August, 2005.  Slightly hazy, golden colour with a thick white head that fades to a long lasting lace.  Smells fantastic, sweet smell of raisins over wheat and barley malt.  Slight hints of alcohol, yeast, and some clove.  Taste delivers what the smell promised, dried fruit, spices especially pepper, fading into slightly phenolic hops.  Finish lasts and lasts.  I loved this and would definately buy it again.

750 ml. green champagne bottle. Corked and caged. Best before date of 01/01/2007. Must be really fresh then. Loud pop actually shot the cork out forcefully. Good thing I had a grip on it. Poured out a dark straw yellow color, with a neverending humongous white, meringue like head. Thick enough to float a bottle cap.
Aromas are of fresh cut hay, spicy apricots, some pineapple, and lactic wheat notes. Big yeast presence as well. Thick matting and huge lacing from the beer. Very effervescent, highly carbonated. Carbonic bite is present in the mouthfeel, but nothing overpowering.
Rich, thick mouthfeel, and spicy hops blend to make an excellent triple. I really like this one. You might too.
Orange golden body with a nice white foamy head. Yeasty, fruity and hoppy aroma with hay notes. Bitter/sour flavor with lots of fruit, hops and citrus.

mostly clear, medium golden color, with light carbonation and a dense white head. perfumey aroma with lots of yeast, and some mustiness and some bubble gum and maybe a little citrus? flavor has a little barnyard, a little lemon. i can detect a little hop in the finish, but not too much.

11.2 oz capped bottle: pours crystal clear golden straw.  Medium, white, fluffy head.  Floral grass aroma with a good bit of sticky malt.  A light, airy yeast comes into play as well.  Full, lucious flavours of perfume, banana, sourdough, honey, and lemony hops.  Texture is fairly chewy with a yeasty overtone, which I enjoyed.  Special thanks to my secret santa, aofoxxy.

Quite possibly the finest tripel I have ever tasted.  Could that be that it has been a week since my last beer, and weeks since my last tripel?  Beautiful clear golden color, very complex flavor, reminding me slightly of more aromatic and robust German hefeweizens.  Sweetens on the finish as it warms.

Slightly hazy orange with dense, substantial white head. Aroma is filled with wood notes (oak and cedar) and slightly sour. Flavor isdensely fruity (apricots) and bready/yeasty, altogether a little sticky. Slightly burnt/dry hoppiness. Very nuanced and quite nice.

The glass it is usually served in costs more than the beer itself. This makes for a good overall impression. The beer has a golden color and strong fruitflavor. An aquired taste perhaps, but this is the best I've tasted yet.
Yellow orange color with a large fizzy head.  Spicy aroma with candi sugar, mustiness and a hint of lemons.  Rich flavor that reminds me of dark bread.  Full bodied, and ends dry.

bottle-12/27/03 RB three floyds gathering.  spicy/candy aroma-lots of sweetness.  Orange/apple palate flavors.  very pale yellow for a tripel, but the flavor makes up for it.  this is the perfect beer to detect coriander in the aroma-textbook example!
One of my favorites.  I love the floral nose and the sweet flavor.  Could be the moswt drinkable 8% beer in the world

Bright golden.  Full fluffy head, rocky.  Full lemony aroma.  Tart and refreshing.  Coriander flavors, plus candy sweet and unlike most other tripels in its focused and full sweetness.  Near cloying, but earthy and barnyardy provide some contrast to balance.  Berries come through later?  The more I drink, the more I get from this and the better I like it.

Bottle, from The Offie, Leicester. Sweet, Wit beerish, floral aroma. Ruddy/golden colour. Slim, white head, which lingers with good lacing. Lemony taste, crisp, light. Only a hint of the ABV, in the aftertaste, with a small, hoppy hurdle, and a little bit of peach. Delicious, and more like a quality Wit beer than a Tripel.

While I truly appreciate what American's are doing with beer, reaching for a Belgian like this still makes me the happiest. Cornucopia of fruit - peaches, apples, bananas, pears... Floral, but ever so lightly. Clove and pepper spiciness. Honey kissed -  just like the color. Sweetness comes like it's from naturally ripened fruit. Very light and airy.
Clear peach color with a frothy white head. Strong clove aroma with a hint of pepper. Very sweet clove flavor, with caramel and a peppery bite to it. Very tingly feel, slightly dry finish.

Pure, clear, deep golden color with a large, frothy white head. The aroma was full of clove, bubblegum, sugar, pepper, and other spices. The flavor was very sweet, very spicy with a strong coriander aftertaste. The feel was rather bubbly, slightly thick with a medium dry finish.

Nice amber color,medium sized white head that lasted for a decent amount of time then faded to a small lace.The aroma was citrusy and floral with maybe a spicy note to it.The flavor was fantastic,nicely fruity with a decent malt side light caramel and spicy with some sweet and light sour notes coming on as the brew warms.The finish is and fruity.Very nice brew with that manages to stya fairly well balanced and flavorful with the alcohol being there but not in a over powering amount.Well worth trying again.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2004 creamy, mellow, fantastic sweetness, pleasantly soft "jump" of leathery, uhm. exotic spice, and sour berry buried within bitterness. i obviously need to drown my nose and tongue in this to figure it all out. UPDATE 8/31/04: again, i need to try it again. so soft and delicious. lively spiced mouthful of cremey bittersweetness. honey citrus pie.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004 Small white head that leaves excellent lacework all the way down the glass. Complex spice and fruit aromas. Sweet caramel maltiness with complex spice undertones, warming from the alcohol, a fantastic beer that i highly recommend.

White weak small head. Deep golden slightly cloudy color. Aroma is fruity (apricots) with a few orange and spicy notes. Flavor is initially moderately sweet with coriander tones, turning in a strong fruity taste preparing a sweet finish. Medium bodied.
UPDATED: JUN 7, 2005 (Bottle)  Pours a hazy maze color with a impressive thick white head, which had great staying power.  Has flavors of citrus, carmel, and floral.

Wow this started off with a banh, the cork shot off before I could even get the wire hood off.  Slight foam in the neck of bottle.  Poured slightly cloudy, due to carbonation pop and settled with a nice white dense head.  Aroma was yeasty and phenolic with hints of citrus, must and apricots.  The taste is sweet/vinous that leads to caramel notes and aromatic malts.  Spicy at first, but seems to meld into a more bready and floral flavor.  Great beer with pasta (I had some Pasta a la Carabonara and it went nicely!!)  I would buy again...

Bottle pours a crystal clear amber color with a real nice head and quite a bit of lace.  the aroma is citrus rind, ripe cheese, and bread.  The flavor is sweet honey and sour  lemon, wheat, caramel, musty, and spicy.  As it warms, it starts to show it bit of the ripe cheese in the flavor.  The palate is medium rich and almost spritzy.  Overall, this beer is complex and not to be approached lightly.

Super clear golden yellow with some steady distributed carbonation bubbles flowing within, a finger high white head of thick froth that retains for a bit, settles to a thick puffed haze on top remaining present the whole glass down, lace begins as sheets but falls apart quickly leaving webby globs. 

Aroma is quite complex and very interesting with a ton of stuff going on, mainly an overall dulled orange peel zest with a sweet sour dough bread rolled into a musty/musky yeastyness that gives it a nice smokey appeal that gives it some brothyness and makes it almost seem like the fruit has rotted or something. Doesn't sound good but man its nice, notes of banana, nectarine, lime, lemon zest, pepperjack, moldy wood, wet dirt, onion, tomato, boy I could continue with all the soupy & fruity things mixing in the smell of this thing but I think I'll stop there before my nose explodes. Wow!

Surprisingly enough the taste comes across nearly the same as the smell but its not as potent and not quite as complex as what the smell hints too. There's a nice tangy sour dough bread malt sweetness to its front, oats and wheat make for some incredible sweetening and the middle is speckled with notes of different dullish citrus fruits of orange, lemon, pineapple, and lime, some slight yeasty tang and light spice of clove and meat broth makes a brief appearance as not to overwhelm that are note worthy from midway all the way to the finishing areas where it leaves more twangy sweetness and light citrus in the finish. 

Feel is a solid medium body with a wierd smoothness thats hard to fathom, but reminded me of light soup. Whats with the soup aspects of this beer? Actually has a nice hold of carbonation that seems to fit the citrusy sweetness and the finish has a subtle complexity of things portrayed in the smell. Politely skipping across is a lime-like twinge left on the lips after each sip. One hell of an interesting Triple, this is more of what I look for from a Triple other then a mega hefe profile of clove and yeast thats been multiplied. This was very interesting and now I am left wondering if its like this all the time. Reviews of this seem to be widely diverse so I will definately get some more soon and try again to make sure this is something that continues to comes across as the same. Either way; this bottle was all Yum!!

Sweet herbal and citrus aroma. Lightly cloudy orange/gold with a big meringue fluffy head and evident mid size chamagne looking bubbles. Leaves heaps of lacing. Initially almost honey like background flavours with citrus and sweet herbal overtones matching the aroma. As my palate adjusted to this brew I notice some more lightly sour fruit flavours making it even more enjoyable. I love the look of the label.
Very light smooth, citrus finish, great head to start off, not overly sweet due to bittery surfaces. GREAT BEER!!

Nice triple with a smooth mouthfeel.  Good head on the pour, though the retention isn't great.  Big up front, quite carbonated, with sour/citrus finish.  Excellent triple, especially at $6.99/750ml, which is what they sell it for at my supermarket (in NYC, no less).  Perhaps the best thing about it is the glass -- overly large and bell-shaped.

Light golden and mostly clear with a big-bubbled head that quickly fades to a thin layer of white. Mouthfeel is smooth up front; becomes more champagne-like toward the finish. Sweet and honey-like malt base. Citrusy (lemon and maybe even a hint of orange), piney, spicy (clove, pepper, coriander, and something else I can't define) and aromatic (herbs, perfume). Grassy bitterness surfaces in the aftertaste; just enough to quench out the sweetness. Overall, a pretty good tripel with a nice bouquet of aromatics.

the same stone-washed canary yellow as a weizen. in the brief tumult of pouring, the head rises like a scone, crackling like rice krispies-- but little of that puffery lingers. like tossing aside it's coat in a boxing match, it bullys up with just a thin white t-shirt of foam.  candied pineapple aroma, dutch butter cookie malts, woody spices. honey wine flavor, ginger apple and hard candy. and yes, lots of caramel yin and yanging with sauterne sweetness.  i frankly failed to note the bitterness so i checked the ultimate beer dictionary: ecrvich's rating-- which confirms that there really wasn't any.  a great beer with so little bitterness is quite an accomplishment.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2004 33cl Bottle, In't Spinnekopke, Brussels, Belgium: Pours golden with a touch of orange. Thick creamy white head. Big hop aroma. Fruity body. Spicy and refreshing but packs a whallop.Very good.

Very well made beer, unfortunately just not quite my thing.  Orangey gold color, hazy, quickly subsiding head.  Aroma was a riotous blast of Belgian funk, spicy and very yeasty.  Flavor was initially yeasty, with pepper, spice, oatmeal, and, sadly, anise.  The licorice flavor grew as it warmed, eventually overwhelming the other notes in the beer.  And I hate licorice.  Disappointing, I had been looking forward to this.  But I can definitely see why others might really enjoy this.

I‚Äôve had this 750ml bottle Tripel Karmeliet for a couple of months now and the temptation finally became too overwhelming, this beast is mine, and I have the proper drinking snifter as well! 
 Damn, the cork must have had rocket boosters attached, The body is a glowing golden / orange, like a jack-o-lantern, a huge pillow of fine silky head, an unmatched appearance. The nose is a yeasty and sweet, note of honey and orange. The flavor is also yeasty, spicy; loads of independent notes of citrus, tangerines are most prevalent, hints of coriander and black pepper. This is truly a pleasant experience. 
 This Tripel has a rather effervescent body, almost champagne like but far more oily. The finish is sweet, dry and crisp, I freaking love it!
This is good Abbey Triple.  Citric, spicy, and sweet flavors but a little too sweet for my tastes.  Finishes clean, crisp, and dry.

Crystal clear, golden ale with a big, long lasting head. ARomas of fruit, candy sugar and malt, with some mustiness. Comes across spicy and highly carbonated, but with a strong fruity-sweet backbone. Finishes hoppy and sweet. Carbonation is a bit too strong.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2005 Brilliant appearance - initially appeared quite fizzy but settled down to a clear gold with amazing head and lacing. 
Aroma was a bit milder than I remember but full of fruits and spices. Flavour quite orange juice-sweet but in a brilliant way, cut by the spicy flavours and alcohol. Reminiscent of a wit in a lot of ways, and completely lacking hop character without missing anything.
Carbonation perhaps slightly too high for my liking but the slight fizz really works with the flavours. Great stuff. (4.5)Re-rate: Had this in Belgium and I just can¬ít keep it at such a high rating. It¬ís still very good, but the slight soapy edge and lack of a really good aroma mean it has to move down.

The warmer this beer became, the better it tasted in my opinion. It poured a large sized white frothy, creamy head that contained fine sized bubbles that was mostly lasting. The body was cloudy with lively carbonation and a golden hue. The nose was fruity, spicy, coriander and some clove. The flavor was fruity, sweet, some spiceness and smooth. The mouthfeel was a little tingly, smooth and bubbly with a thin texture. It was light bodied with good lacing.

This brew poured a large head of foamy finely sized long lasting slowly diminishing bubbles that left behind a carbonated transparent straw yellow colored body behind.   The aroma is mild but full of fruity tones like coriander apricot and oranges.  The mouthfeel is smooth yet bubbly with a nice diminishing finish.  The flavor is also smooth with notes of flowers fruit and mild spices.  An interesting mixture to say the least.  Not as great as the reviews led me to anticipate, but still a fine interesting beer.

What's a Witbier doing in this bottle?  Coriander and citrus (perhaps a hint of orange or lemon) dominate the aroma.  Hazy orange body topped by a thin off-white head.  Rich, powerful flavor: orange, coriander, a touch of sweet caramel, and alcohol notes.  I understand the hype.

Huge fluffy white head that sticks around. Aroma of dough, mild citrus and spice. It has an unbelievable creamy mouthfeel. Many of the standard belgian flavors and a mild sweet caramel malt flavor which makes for a very nice beer.
Pours a light slightly hazy orange-gold.  Huge white head.  Apple and coriander notes in the nose, sweet on the tongue, very minimal hop bite at the end.  Fantastic velvet mouthfeel.
An excellent tripel. Slightly hazy gold color, large white head. Citrusy and spicy. Very smooth, dry finish. Much better than the Kwak that this brewery makes.

Huge head of fine bubbles.  Massive carbonation that keeps a fine head throughout the drink of dense creamy foam.  Does not appear to be bottle conditioned with no sediment present.  Medium gold in color.  Aroma of spices, wheat and a little lemon.  Flavor is very crisp, clean and delicious.  More wheat, spices, lemon and a hint of alcohol.  Very refreshing also.  Finish is smooth and well balanced with a slight alcohol warming.  One of the best triples I have had.
Fine orange color, big head. Citrus-notes in aroma, some sourness. Malt in the flavor, orange too. Some oak???

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2003 This beer rocks!
As soon as the cage was removed, the cork shot off like a rocket... no lie. It's all good fun until someone loses an eye.
If poured gently, the ale is crystal clear and deeply golden. Huge, frothy, white head which diminishes into a small, lasting creamy one. Icecicle lacing
The nose is very floral and spicy. Coriander, white wine, bread dough, apricot and perfume.
The flavor is malty, but well-balanced with notes of white wine, fuzzy fruit, spicy hops and alcohol.
Medium-bodied with a sandy, dry mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation.
Short, extremely astringent, dry finish. Bone dry!
World class brew!

Yeasty, doughy, and fruity sweet, flowery aroma. Clear golden body, with a massive white head. Starts with a delicate sweetness, plum flavors, very lightly spiced. Refreshing hops in the finish. Excellent tripel.

This is a nice foggy yellow color. A thin but decent head, very bubbly. A pleasant, but strong caramel smell. The palate is strong , the flavor is bitter, sharp, and a bit buttery, esters, a strong, slightly sweet corriander flavor.

Clear golden, huge fluffy white head. Citrus, pears, yeast and white pepper in aroma. Floral and very fruity flavour with hints of lemon, honey, guava and spices. Sparkling palate with some yeastiness. Spicy and very fruity finish with some warming alcohol notes. A beautiful beer.
Beautiful beer, great head.  It's got some kick for having a sweet, fruity aroma.

Crystal clear yellow color with a white, medium sized head. Aroma is yeasty, fruity, and sweet, with Belgian candi sugar obvious and a hint of honey and lemon. Flavor is sweet and malty, with a significant alcohol presence in the finish. Unlike some triples I've had, carbonation is not overbearing. A very nice brew.

Corked bottle; opened up like Champagne with beer shooting out of the top. I really liked this, but in comparison to the Duvel it seemed to be missing something to balance the sweetness. Still, it is a very drinkable complex brew (can hardly taste the alcohol) with a better mouth feel when it warms up slightly to around cellar temps.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2003 (33o ml bottle) Large, white, foamy head and light golden body. Tornado of carbonation climbing the stem of the glass. Very pleasant aroma of a flamb√© banana mixed with peach and apricots and lightly spiced with cinnamon. Light on the tongue with bananas and lemons dancing across the palate. Same herbal yeast as I found in Charlevoix 8e Jour. Excellent beer. Love to have another dozen or so. Many thanks to Lubi√®re for this opportunity!

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2005 Nice presentation: a big glass with lily flowers drawn on. I just had to hunt and buy one. Hazy golden color with a pretty fine white head, rather large, but it doesnt stay up its throne long. Superb aroma of flowers and fruits. I¬ím really tempted. Very complex flavor developments in mouth. I can¬ít count all those fruits: orange, banana, apples, lemon. Was that butter? Spicy, yeasty. Refreshing tartness spreading out, more hops than most triples. Comfortable medium mouthfeel that bites the tongue a bit when too fresh, it¬ís so easy to drink it¬ís not even funny. Pleasant aftertaste. Almost ridiculously complex. The perfect type of beer I wish to have more of immediatly once I¬ím done with the first bottle. Delicious, the best tripel I¬íve had up to now. Two thumbs up.  A recent sampling have changed my opinion a bit. Either I was less sensible or it just isn¬ít as pleasant to me, but the coriander sums to a bit too much. It remains very complex, but despite remembering it very sweet, I remembered more noble and juicy hops procuring more balancing bitterness. For now, it remains way above your average triple, but I can¬ít like it as much as Allagash. Bumping down from 4.6 to 4.2. Still loving the way those cereals work together, the nose is great and expressive, but I¬íd like it more with more hops and less coriander.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2003 Pours a light gold color with a large Altostratus cloud head. Sticks to the glass with excellent precision. Aroma is toasty with a apricot and apple aroma, vinous but smooth, slightly tart and soapy. Some barny complexities come in the note after a strenuous sniffing session. Flavor is smooth and initially full of citrus from the hops then finishes with a biscuit malt background. Rolls right through your tongue and into your palate. Once it's there it feels slightly musky but dry. This has many hidden complexities which can not be revealed in just a small sample, this demands a full service tasting session of its own.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 Damp cloudiness.  Decent big white head.  Smells of cloves, flowers, peahes, and orange peel.  Thick and sticky, fruit and sugar up front, very punchy.  Mild carbonation and alcohol presence.  Entirely too sweet.

Tasty stuff. Got a bottle at chinatwon cellars the other day walking home... If you try hard you get a hint of salami in the aroma and there is a little popcorn which goes well with the buttery malt palate. It goes down real smooth which suits me fine. The head poured huge at first but almost completely died away towards the end of my glass, oh well. Anyway, I could get into this stuff; classy.
Excellent Belgian beer, but aren't they all? This one is strong with a firm but not overpowering fruit taste.
A golden body with a white frothy 2 finger head. The banana aroma was mixed with florals. The flavor is floral as well with nice spice and a hint of caramel as it warms. Nice carbonation as well.

If this is not the best Belgium beer, then I have much drinking to do of other more highly rated Belgiums! (when its available here in Australia) I will leave room in my rating until I taste better, which I guess I will.  But this beer was a good drop of mother's fine milk  and very easily downed with room left for another.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010  3/03/04My rating is for a 75cl corked green bottle. This one opened like champagne and poured just the same with a high carbonation and a champagne like head. The head settles down to a creamy dense froth and rests there the duration. Lacing is subtle and scattered inside the glass in various places. Tiny streams of bubbles rise gallantly from the bottom of the glass throughout the session. Aroma is fruity and spicy with a subtle earthiness to it. The mouthfeel is like a comfortable pillow, smooth and delicate with a warming finish. Flavor is as complex as any good Tripel I¬íve had and the use of three grains enhances the complexity even more. Fruity, earthy sweet and a full complex malt flavor. Yeast is also very much in the flavor. This bottle was good to the very last drop and I enjoyed it completely. 5/30/10 RE-RATE I¬ím moving this one up to my top Tripel. A 33cl bottle as fresh as you can get.  Same cloudy appearance with an initially large snow white head tha reduces to a layer of film. Beautiful aroam which is peppery, floral doughy and with  really great yeast notes. Lively carbonation, slightly sweet and peppery in flavor with some really nice hops. A very enjoyable brew and now my favoritre Tripel!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
Beautiful beer in an even more beautiful glass. Nice, tight head holding fairly well. A little yeasty, no alcahol feel(wich is nice). Very nice full, well rounded body. And there are alot of fruits in the aftertaste.
This beer is a little light but still it has that richness.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2013 yeasty aroma, tiny fruit hints but not much. Almost perfect looking for a blonde, clear light orange colour and a really thick white head. Nice sweet spicyness, a VERY pleasent beer!! extra points for a beautiful glass!!!!  thanks Eirikur 4.7

re-rated 18-7-2012
very light in color.  Alot of carbanation.  Not much flavor though.  I thought it was too sweet.

Golden with a large frothy head.
Yeasty, fruity citrus aroma.
Champagnelike palate.
A short pleasant bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2005  Bottled. Rerate.  Pours a beautiful golden/amber body with a rich lasting head. Notes of tropical fruits(apricot, pineapple?) and banana in the aroma. Soft maltiness, with a slight sugary sweetness up front followed up by that tidbitty flavour of banana, and vanilla.  Warming liquer-like finish. Stunningly tasty triple.

Dusty peach-gold, sticky white head.  Nose is floral and yeasty, slightly fruity.  Flavor would be best described as simply spectacular.  Very yeasty, blends beautifully with sugared bananas and oranges.  Nice spiciness, a bit bready.  Very sharp and tart at the swallow, smoothes out to a pleasing breadiness.  Nice fizz, just all around a lovely, lovely beer.

Golden amber, dense and big white head.  Powdery aroma of orange, pollen, with herbal notes, icing sugar, banana in the finish.  These components all blend together in the flavor department with an added touch of light acidity to it.  Why did I only buy three bottles?  WHY?!?!?!?

Another exploding cork from a belgian 750 ( see my rating of Browsel 20). Huge head, predictably. I really didn't find the aroma that great, it was kind of skunky in fact. ..ah, there we go....less head if you drink straight from the bottle. Taste is mainly just sweetness until the finish. Then that colorful, slightly dry triple taste comes in and makes itself known. Easy drinking at 8%, very well masked.
Golden pour with pleny of carbonation.  Citrus nose with a fair amount of head.  Sweet fruity flavor, with nice lace throughout.
Nice golden ale color with bursts of carbonation; frothy, long-lasting head; smooth but somewhat light texture; very nice taste with hints of honey and a slightly sweet aftertaste

mmm mmm mmm, yummy...good to the last drop.  POurs a cloudy golden color, with a creamy egg like head.  Great aroma, but the taste is just exquisite and unrivaled.  A new flavor is unmasked with eac sweet sip, the first being slightly reminiscent of granny smith apples, following with bananas, raspberries, cloves and spices with a bittersweet clove honey aftertaste.  About hlafway through the lacing really becomes a joy to watch from rich and creamy in the finish w/ a bitterness and clove bite right to the final finish.

Bottled: sour citrus and yeast aroma with a beautiful colour/presentation. Pillowy white head, smooth easy drinking body with a wonderfully complexity. Great balance. Recommended. I'm off to buy some more.
Poured a golden color with a white fizzy head that left no lacing.  Sweet fruity aroma, with a sweet taste.  Alcohol burn on the way down.

Lovely yellow hue infused with continuous (I mean it!) strings of little bubbles.  With its fresh, sugar nose and immediate zing (it stings - hurts almost, but in a good way), and smooth, round palate, this is an excellent tripel!  It's subtle yet full of joie de vivre!

tap at the toronado.... large sweet scent to it, that was malty with loads of caramel, was lightly colored with an enormous head, flat and overly sweet in my mouth, had a rejectful gagging palate to it, made me very unhappy reminded me almost of Nostradamus

Bottled. Sparkly golden colour with rising stars. Fine, thin, lacy white head. Complex blend of sweet malts. Cinnamon and fine caramel flavours. Large, full and complex palate. You could enjoy this beer very, very slowly for maximum flavour or just hold back enough to get the rate in. Extra ethanol towards the finish, otherwise another superb finisher.
Heavy and sweet. Not as yeasty as many other regular Belgian triples. Well-balanced. Pretty dominant alcoholic taste.
Huge white head, sweet perfumed-fruit nose, light golden body with moderate carbonation. A slow pour. Very smooth and complex.
Sweet abbey ale with hints of spice and a nice strong fruit - maybe some burnt orange.  Bit of a thick aftertaste.  Mine was far too carbed from the bottle which was a nuisance.

This Abbey Tripel was to sweet for my liking, although it has a great aroma and poured nicely. Taste was very fruity, with a nice spicy hints included. I must try this one again with a good cheese, to compliment its taste.

Clear light yellow-gold. Lively pearling to thick, fluffy white irregular head. Nose of grain, wheat, a little smoked smell. After a while, a sharp roasted malt smell comes up, spicy. Sweet, malty taste, but with a sharp, nearly adstringent mouthfeel, like partly roasted malt - strange for such a pale beer. The oats? Spicy and fruiy, but foremost malty. As said, sharp mouthfeel, medium-bodied. It could be refreshing but for that roasted flavour. A beer with a very high emphasis on grain and malt. Not uninteresting, but not very exciting. A bit of a hype, and with the role of the spectacular glass, that sounds familiar for this brewery.
In bottel at The Belgique in Amsterdam, and many times throughout Belgium. Big giant white head. Oaty aroma, sweet malt. Caramel and sweet butter (not diacetyl) flavors. On the sweet side.

In bottle at Flying Saucer in Ft. Worth Texas. Dark slightly hazy yellow hue with a small rocky head and almost no lacing, medium-bodied. Moderate hoppy (3 types of hops used I was told), perfume, fruity sweet aroma of raisin and apple. Undertones of spices and grains. Beautiful tart and sweet flavor balance with sublime spice accent. A bit thin mouthfeel, lively. Near world-class, thanks to the manager for sharing this with me.
Good color and nice head. Sweet, hoppy, spicy well balanced with carbonation. This is robust and yummy!

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 It took me 434 beers before i tried this one. Why did i wait so long!? In my opinion it¬ís the best tripel around. Aroma and flavour of malts, hops, fruit, spices and some sweetness. Fairly complex and very well balanced. Btw my rating represents the bottled version, on tap it¬ís not nearly as good.
Nice color with a nice white foam. Beautiful glas gets it one point more in appearance. Taste is sweet, with hints of parfume or soap.
